PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Nuclear Disarmament
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
(1) Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

(2) Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territories.
(3) Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

(4) Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1% of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other states.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatently discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80 per day in the other states. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $ 40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of Government Standard Costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from seven citizens) and Robertson (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Exportation of Kangaroo Products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Local Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the requirement that pensioners and health care cardholders fill in a complex declaration when presenting prescriptions is causing distress to beneficiaries and inefficiencies in the distribution of medicines by pharmacists .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will immediately abolish the requirement that a declaration be completed by the pensioner and health care cardholder.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill gives effect to the Government's announced decision to amend section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. This section was amended last year as part of the Medicare legislation package because of concern expressed by both Commonwealth and State governments about the lack of controls over rights of private practice in public hospitals.

Briefly, section 17 provides that Medicare benefits are not payable in respect of a prescribed medical service rendered to private patients in or at a public hospital unless there is an agreement in writing between the medical practitioner and the public hospital. The agreement must conform to guidelines determined by the Commonwealth Minister for Health.

This concern about lack of controls over private practice rights in public hospitals, especially in the area of diagnostic services, is well documented. The previous Government commissioned the Jamison inquiry into the efficiency and administration of hospitals. That report made the following recommendations:

Recommendation 109: There be an urgent review by each of the employment authorities of rights of private practice in hospitals with a view to limiting its scope, consistent with the underlying intent of the contract between an individual patient and doctor.
Recommendation 111: Steps be taken to phase out over a period of years the right of private practice for full time salaried specialists.
Recommendation 112: Action be taken to improve the awareness of all medical practitioners of the medical value and cost of tests, not only for pathology but for all diagnostic services.
Recommendation 113: Guidelines be issued by health authorities on the utilisation of radiology pathology and pharmacy services.

These are strong recommendations from what is generally accepted as being a very conservative report. Their concern was obviously aroused by the evidence given by many organisations about excess utilisation of diagnostic services in hospitals. Let me quote what the Australian Association of surgeons told the Jamison inquiry:

'There are cases of patients tested to the point of exhaustion for reasons entirely unknown to their principal medical attendant. There is little doubt that many of these diagnostic testing procedures represent an unwarranted invasion of privacy inflicted on the patient and many of them cause unnecessary suffering and hardship. Their cost to the community is almost inestimable.'
This type of statement which was made by several other conservative and respected organisations prompted the Jamison commission of inquiry to state in its report:

'The commission realises that patients would want their doctors to explore all available avenues in times of doubt. But the statements above must cause concern to patients, doctors, administrators and governments.'
Unfortunately the matter was of no concern to the previous Government, who took no action in this area despite the strong recommendations and evidence of the inquiry that it had commissioned.

This Government does not believe that questions such as the rapidly increasing cost of diagnostic services can be ignored. We are dedicated to the operation of an efficient, high standard health care system, and we intend to provide this through Medicare at a cost that is affordable to the Australian people. It was vital that at the same time as we introduced Medicare we introduced meaningful measures to restrain increases in health costs in some areas. Given the statement I have just quoted from the surgeons association, it is not difficult to see why it was decided that the area of diagnostic services was in need of immediate attention.

Some medical specialists have viewed section 17 as a threat to their income and privileges, and as a result they have embarked on a course of industrial action. The Government has made every effort to be reasonable on this issue, as this Bill and the deferral of more controversial matters to the joint Government/ Australian Medical Association Penington inquiry clearly indicates. However, our overriding responsibility is to ensure that the $2,000m in Medicare benefits paid annually to medical practitioners in this country, is wisely and properly spent. For this reason we cannot and will not be deterred from the principal of section 17, or the fairness of the guidelines relating to schedule fee compliance that have already been introduced under the section. These guidelines , which were developed in consultation with State Governments, and after considerable discussion and compromise with the AMA, were gazetted on 29 February 1984. These guidelines are not in the form of a regulation and therefore, under the current legislation not subject to disallowance by the Parliament.

The Government believed this was unnecessary because the circumstances of doctor's employment in public hospitals made it impossible for any government to use section 17 to impose unreasonable conditions. Firstly, in acting in this area any government would need the co-operation of a majority of the State governments, who would not act to endanger the standards of their own public hospital system. Secondly, the specialists who are at the forefront of this dispute are not salaried specialists, they are independent enterpreneurs who work in the public hospital system only part of the time. If a government were foolish enough to impose unreasonable guidelines under section 17, then these specialists would have an immediate recourse to withdraw to their already established private practices outside public hospitals. They obviously do not need the direct protection of law necessary for a salaried employee.

Thirdly, and most obviously, it would not be in the interests of any government , especially a Labor Government, to introduce guidelines that prompted an exodus of specialists from the public hospital system, we are dependent on these people for the excellence of care that is currently provided in our public hospitals. Rights of private practice are an important element in attracting high quality medical staff to the public hospitals. This Government believes that while some of those private practice rights are in need of reform, that it would be counter -productive in the extreme to abolish them.
The points I have just made were summarised in the Sydney Morning Herald's editorial of Saturday, 17 March 1984, as follows:

'What, exactly, is at issue in the two month old industrial dispute between the doctors and the Federal Government? Is it, as the doctors claim, the unfettered power given to the Federal Health Minister by section 17 of the Health Insurance Act? Hardly. Dr Blewett's power under section 17 is certainly no more and probably a great deal less than that of any other employer. In theory, he can do almost anything he likes. In practice, he is limited by both the doctors' industrial power and public opinion.'

Now that is a realistic statement of the real position in the real world. However, the paranoia and unwarranted fear that the AMA and specialist groups have aroused in the medical profession, in the interests of furthering an industrial dispute over income and privileges, has meant that the Government now finds it necessary to formalise that real world situation into legislation. For that reason this Bill has been introduced as it meets the objections of principle put forward by the medical profession, and should lead to an end to the current industrial disruption before it seriously endangers patient welfare.

Let me remind the Senate again of the facts about private practice rights in public hospitals. There are a variety of different schemes and arrangements under which salaried doctors exercise rights of private practice. There is lack of detailed knowledge about how such schemes operate, and how a substantial proportion of the funds available under those schemes are applied. It is a fact that receipt of Medicare benefits by salaried hospital specialists provides them with a source of income, over and above their salary determinations. This private practice income is generally accrued during the same working time in which they are employed by the public hospital.

This is why it is nonsense for the AMA and the Opposition to object to the Commonwealth Government having a say in the conditions under which doctors are employed in public hospitals. Those agreements between hospitals and doctors directly effect the amount of Medicare benefits that the Commonwealth Government is liable to pay. State governments have no direct monetary interest in controlling the amount of private practice work undertaken in public hospitals, however, the four State Labor governments have accepted the reality of the problem and willingly cooperated in the development of guidelines under section 17.

As I have already made clear, this Government has no intention of abolishing rights of private practice arrangements in public hospitals, despite the recommendation of the Jamison inquiry. Our intention is only to impose reasonable controls to ensure that those rights are not exploited. Our concerns have been greatest about rights of private practice as it relates to diagnostic services, pathology, radiology, radiotherapy, and nuclear medicine. In these areas, there is little if any direct doctor-patient contact, and the patient is usually unaware of the nature and extent of any tests being carried out. This is a high cost area of Medicare which provides substantial scope for generating additional revenue. There is also a significant technical content to these services as provided by the use of public hospital equipment and facilities. It is because these costly facilities are taxpayer funded that we are expecting a wider degree of public accountability from these diagnostic specialists.

The Government has made no secret of the fact, from before the legislation passed by this Parliament in September last year, that Medicare benefits would be payable for these diagnostic services provided in public hospitals, only if the service was provided in accordance with an agreement between the doctor and the public hospital. Prior to that, the Government had commenced negotiations with the Australian Medical Association. The initial draft guidelines proposed that all agreements would require:
(a) All accounts to be raised by the hospital on behalf of the doctor.
(b) All charges to be at or below schedule fee.
(c) All revenue received for diagnostic services rendered under private practice contracts for full time specialists in a particular hospital to be treated as one fund.
(d) The fund to be applied in the following order:
(1) Facility charges (recovery of costs) to the hospital in a form acceptable to the Commonwealth Minister.
(2) Drawings by the doctor at a level determined by the State, up to 25 per cent of full time specialist salary.
(3) Any residual to be applied following guidelines set by the State Ministers for Health.
The purpose of those guidelines was to:

(1) Standardise private practice rights for full time salaried staff. In most States, the 25 per cent limit already applied, except in New South Wales where some more generous arrangements apply in some cases.

(2) Reduce incentives for visiting private practitioners to request and perform tests. In some areas where there is a shortage of salaried staff, visiting practitioners perform most, if not all, the radiological or pathology services. This means that the fee for services payment systems allows these practitioners to generate substantial income, in such circumstances, it was reasonable to introduce income restraints as they meant that necessary diagnostic services would be performed at a more reasonable cost to taxpayers. These guidelines were in no sense harsh by community standards since they did not have any effect until an income of about $62,500 per annum was reached.
Because of the AMA's dissatisfaction with these arrangements, a further proposal, inter alia, was made on income levels. It was proposed that:
For full time, salaried staff
(i) Drawings by the doctor, up to 25% of the salary of a senior specialist. ( Allows about $12,500 pa from private practice on top of a salary of about $50, 000 pa)
For visiting, private practitioners
(i) Full drawings by the doctor, up to 125% of the salary of a senior specialist (about $62,500 pa)
(ii) From 125% to 175% of the senior specialist salary (about $62,500 to $87, 500 pa), the doctor can draw 75% of the earnings above $62,500 pa and leave 25% in the fund.
(iii) Above 175% of the senior specialist salary (about $87,500 pa), the doctor can draw 60% of the earnings above $87,500 pa and leave 40% in the fund.

Any residual remaining in the fund to be applied for purposes such as education , equipment or other development activities under guidelines set by the State Health Minister. These more generous limits were also not acceptable to the AMA.

On 11 January 1984, the Minister for Health met with representatives on the AMA about their objections. On 24 January, the Minister announced that the Government would defer implementation of the income restraint guidelines. He also announced that there would be a committee of inquiry into rights of private practice in public hospitals under the chairmanship of Professor David Penington , Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at Melbourne University. The Commonwealth and the AMA were each to nominate a member to constitute a committee of three. The Minister also announced that the introduction of the section 17 arrangements would be deferred from 1 February to 1 March to allow for further negotiation, and to allow a reasonable implementation period for doctors and State Health authorities.

The Minister met with the AMA again on 9 February 1984. The AMA's attention then turned to the Minister's 'unfettered powers' under section 17 to alter their conditions. As indicated previously, it is not in any government's interests to introduce guidelines which change arrangements so significantly as to drive doctors out of the public hospital system. Therefore, in negotiations with the AMA in February, it was agreed that terms of reference for the Penington inquiry would include consultative procedures prior to variation of the guidelines, and appeal or review procedures in relation to these arrangements. The Minister also guaranteed that the guidelines would not be altered or extended until the report of the inquiry had been considered.

The AMA's other objection was that the new national list of facility charges for the prescribed diagnostic items meant increases in those charges in some States for some services. Again, the Government agreed to refer the question of a national list of facility charges to the inquiry, and to allow the existing State facility charges to remain in force until the inquiry reported. The AMA's only concession in all these negotiations was to agree on 16 February to participate in the inquiry. Following this further meeting on 16 February, the Federal President of the AMA, Dr Thompson, publicly stated that the Government's concessions and the inquiry had provided a real basis for resolution of the dispute. However, the Government proposals were rejected by a meeting of the AMA and specialist groups on 22 February 1984.
This situation necessitated joint action by the Ministers for Health in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, and Western Australia to ensure that:
No practitioners providing diagnostic services would charge more than the schedule fee for services in public hospitals after 1 March 1984;
No patient would be denied access to public hospital services and no diagnostician would be prevented from rendering services to his or her patients in a public hospital; and

The medical benefit schedule fee would not be required to be included in agreements under section 17 where a State took action to ensure that the schedule fee was charged for diagnostic services through these limited price control measures.

The guidelines which were introduced on 29 February were revised to ensure that the only significant requirements for the agreements between the hospital and the doctor was that charges raised be at or below the schedule fee. This is not a government fee: It is a fee set annually by an independent arbitrator after hearing argument from government, the AMA, and other interested parties.

Despite all the concessions made, in an effort to reach a settlement, the AMA was still being intransient, so a meeting was held on 2 March with the Prime Minister present, at that meeting, the Prime Minister offered:

(1) To give an undertaking in writing that during the period of the Penington committee inquiry, there will be no change of any sort in the guidelines as gazetted on 29 February 1984 or in the details of their application.

(2) With respect to the recommendations of the Penington committee relating to appeal and review procedures, the government will advise the Penington committee that the government has no objection to recommendations providing for such procedures and will accept the recommendations of the inquiry on that matter.
In return, the Government sought an assurance that the AMA would recommend to the members of the profession:

(1) That they sign written agreements in accordance with current guidelines, with particular emphasis on the guidelines relating to charging at or below the schedule fee, where such arrangements do not already exist.
(2) That there be no discrimination against Medicare-only patients in recognised hospitals.

The Federal AMA agreed this was reasonable and took the Prime Minister's proposal to a further meeting of their State branches, and other medical organisations. This compromise offered by the Prime Minister was also rejected by that meeting.
The A.M.A. and some specialist organisations have now rejected all attempts at a negotiated settlement, and embarked on a campaign of industrial action in an effort to have their total demands met.

Because the Government had twice reached near agreement with the Federal A.M.A. on proposals to resolve the dispute, we believed it was necessary to have a round table conference with all the major groups concerned in the dispute. Several attempts to arrange a meeting between the Minister for Health and State Health Ministers with the Federal and State Branches of the A.M.A. and the college of radiologists have failed, because the medical profession has refused to attend.

Senator Haines of the Australian Democrats put forward a constructive proposal which would give immediate substance to the Prime Minister's undertaking of 2 March to institute appeal provisions into section 17. The Government has adopted that proposal in this Bill, and there can now be no argument that the Minister's powers under section 17 are considerably fettered and restricted-both formally through legislation as well as in practical reality.

The first amendment of section 17 inserts in it a new sub-section (1A) for the purpose of enabling the Minister, if he is satisfied that the laws of a State or Territory, or agreements or arrangements entered into under such laws, are such as will regulate the rendering of a prescribed professional service in a manner consistent with the guidelines, to sign an instrument exempting a medical practitioner from the requirement to enter into an agreement of the kind referred to.

The second amendment adds sub-sections (5), (6), (7), and (8) at the end of section 17. These Provisions will enable the guidelines that have been made by he Minister under section 17, and any guidelines that the Minister makes in the future, to be disallowed in the Parliament in the same way as a Statutory Rule may be disallowed.
By these measures, the two practical objectives of this Bill are achieved. They are:

(1) To provide for Parliamentary scrutiny of the Minister for Health's power to make guidelines. This is the constructive proposal put forward by Senator Haines , and in practice it would mean that the Senate would have power to disallow any guidelines put forward by the Minister that it felt were unreasonable. This meets the major objection of principle put forward by the Medical profession.

(2) to give the option of Medicare Benefits being payable either where there is an agreement in writing between the hospital and the doctor or where State legislation or regulation ensures that the guidelines are complied with. This amendment gives greater flexibility to allow Medicare benefits to be payable, and is designed to protect patients in what is essentially a dispute between Government and the medical profession.

The Government believes these measures are appropriate because our objective has always been to ensure compliance with the schedule fee, and instituting other reasonable reforms to private practice rights in public hospitals-rather than to get signatures on pieces of paper.

In addition, the cabinet has agreed in principle to regular arbitrated review of the schedule fee, and has authorised the Minister for Health to enter into negotiations with the A.M.A. to achieve this.

This should dispel another piece of paranoia now abroad in the medical profession that having secured compliance with the schedule fee it would then allow the schedule fee to stagnate for some years. The speed with which the Government moved to secure an arbitrated interim fee increase once the wage pause was ended should also establish the bona fides of the Government in this matter.

The comments of the Federal President of the A.M.A., Dr Thompson, that Parliamentary scrutiny is not sufficient because at some future time a Government may also have a majority in the Senate, have been noted. I would point out that such a situation could not occur in the time before the Penington inquiry reports. The Guarantee that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health gave on 2 March still stands. That is that the Government will implement whatever consultative and appeal mechanisms are recommended by the Penington inquiry. That remains a term of reference for the inquiry, and the A.M.A. and other medical groups will have ample opportunity to put forward any other consultative and appeal proposals they feel are desirable. The Government will not extend its guidelines beyond schedule fee compliance for diagnostic services during the period of the Penington inquiry.

I believe that the A.M.A. and other medical groups should accept this Bill as substantially achieving their aims in relation to appeal rights under section 17 . It is obvious that any Federal Government would find it impossible to introduce unreasonable guidelines under section 17 because it would require the consent of both Houses of Federal Parliament, and also the agreement of State Parliaments to any complementary legislation or regulations made by State Government.

The Federal Government has no intention of submitting to all the demands made by the A.M.A. We believe that schedule fee compliance by diagnostic specialists in public hospitals is fair and reasonable, and we will not be withdrawing that guideline, the Government has a responsibility to act in the public interest, and to ensure that taxpayers' money provided through the one per cent levy is properly spent. Nor will the Government abandon the principle of section 17 which is designed to ensure that the public hospital system is not exploited by private interests.

The problem with resolving this dispute has been that while the Government has negotiated in good faith, and made several compromises in an effort to resolve it, the A.M.A. has offered nothing. They have not passed on the details of all these concessions to their membership, and this has served to create misunderstandings and inflame emotions in the profession generally. The current industrial strife should now cease.

The introduction of this Bill is a positive step by the Government to seek a resolution of the dispute before the current industrial action which is causing inconvenience to patients escalates to a point where it could endanger patients.

I hope that the majority of the medical profession will accept this public act of good faith by the Government, and cease the current industrial action in the best interests of their patients' welfare. This legislation will provide the immediate safeguards the profession has sought, and the Penington Inquiry provides a proper opportunity for them to raise any further concerns they may have. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1984 seeks to amend the Acts Interpretation Act. It is a Bill which I suppose most people and even some honourable senators would normally regard as a dry as dust legal subject, one of interest solely to a small number of lawyers. The Bill contains a number of proposed amendments which I suppose would come into that category. They indicate the preoccupation of lawyers in their most technical vein. I do not propose to deal with them except to say that the Opposition supports them. As I said, they cover the sort of subjects about which people cannot understand what interests lawyers. I do not intend to detain this chamber in discussing them at all. They are set out in the explanatory memorandums and are dealt with briefly in the second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act is a somewhat notable exception to the usual rule on this subject because it contains a proposal which I believe is of very great significance not only in the approach to statutory interpretation, but also in virtually revolutionising the approach to the drafting of statutes. The proposal is that in interpreting statutes judges may have regard to extrinsic material as an aid in interpretation. The Bill sets out the various extrinsic matters which may be referred to. It is based upon a general proposition that the approach to the subject may include any material not forming part of an Act which is capable of assisting in the ascertainment of the meaning of the provision. However, the proposal does confine that approach in a very important way. That approach can be made only where there is need to confirm that the meaning of the provision is the ordinary meaning contained by the text, taking into account its context in the Act. Of course, the cardinal rule is that one must look at the whole Act and also the purpose or object underlying the Act. That part of the legislation refers to an earlier amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act which I introduced in 1981. It required the courts, in interpreting Acts of Parliament, to have regard to the purpose or object of the Act. The second restriction on the use of extrinsic material is that it can be resorted to to determine the meaning of the provision only when the provision is ambiguous or obscure or the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of the provision, taking into account its context and purpose, is manifestly absurd or unreasonable.

The proper role of the courts in interpreting statutes is a question of legal interest and concern and these have been rules of statutory interpretation for a long time. In the twentieth century there developed a very literal interpretation of statutes. I think this coincided with the retreat by the courts from any claim to a law-making role and the assertion by Parliament of a much greater activity in that law-making role. The two theories seemed to run together. However, in recent years it has become more and more obvious that the literal interpretation of statutes by the courts was an unnecessary and most unfortunate abdication by them of their historic role going back for hundreds of years, when the common law was largely developed by the initiative of judges. It became more and more apparent to parliamentarians, as I think it must be apparent to all of us in this chamber, that it was absurd to believe that Parliament could cope with law making on the scale and in the detail which has become the fashion.

When I opened a symposium on this subject just before the change of government in 1983 I referred to the volume of legislation. I pointed to the then current volume of Acts for 1981 which had just been published. If honourable senators care to look at it they will see that it contains two very fat volumes of 1981 Acts, covering 182 Acts and 2828 pages. There is nothing unique about that; it just happened to be the latest development of this orgy of legislation. Since then the volumes for 1982 have been published. Again there are two volumes, containing 158 Acts and 2,298 pages.

Over recent decades it has become impossible for the Parliament to legislate intelligently in that sort of detail. At the same time it has become more and more obvious that the courts now realise that they should not pursue the purely literal interpretation and that they ought to have more regard to the object and purpose of legislation. They should have a different approach, one which is now being referred to as the purposive approach.

At the time I moved for the insertion of section 15AA into the Acts Interpretation Act in 1981, Australian courts were just tentatively starting to make greater use of that approach. It was the subject of a lot of controversy and still is. I do not deny that. But it is interesting to see the number of cases, particularly in the High Court of Australia and in the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia, where this approach is now being adopted. I will not refer to particular cases, but there is a very noticeable change of approach. Whether the insertion of section 15AA has hastened that change or not is a matter for others to determine in the course of time. I think it has certainly given the courts an indication of what Parliament thinks. It was very gratifying that there was a bipartisan approach to this subject at the time. There was virtually a unanimous view in this Parliament that it was the right approach. I think that must have been of some significance for the judges.

That approach was only one step. It is certainly necessary, if the courts are to adopt this wider, more flexible, approach, that they should not be bound, as they thought they were, to interpret a statute very strictly within the four corners of the statute itself. Another burning topic for many years has been what judges may look at extrinsic to the Act. This subject has certainly interested me for many years.

Coupled with the introduction of the new approach in this amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act I instructed the Attorney-General's Department to embark on a consideration of this question. There was a very ready response, particularly from Mr Brazil who is now the Secretary to the Department but who was then a Deputy Secretary and from Mr Geoffrey Kolts, the First Parliamentary Counsel. They prepared a Green Paper, which was tabled in this Parliament, suggesting possible new approaches to the question of what extrinsic material may be considered. As a result of that Paper a symposium was held in early February 1983. It was promoted by the Attorney-General's Department. The symposium attracted enormous interest and support from the leading figures of the legal world in Australia. It was led by a very distinguished former law lord, Lord Wilberforce, who came to Australia for that purpose. The symposium was attended by no less than the Chief Justice and four other justices of the High Court, and many distinguished lawyers. At the end of the day Mr Justice Mason of the High Court acted as rapporteur for the symposium. He set out what he thought were its conclusions. Those conclusions were quoted in the statement of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) made on behalf of the Attorney-General which was incorporated in Hansard on 30 November last year. I will read the general conclusions as seen by Sir Anthony Mason:
the law as it presently stands in relation to extrinsic aids is neither clear nor convincing,
it was generally agreed that cautious use should be made of extrinsic materials and that their potential to assist was restricted to cases of ambiguity;
there were perhaps some misgivings about the use of Hansard, and greater reservations about the use of the old style explanatory memorandum--
that is the one with which we are all familiar-
and also the proposed specially prepared and approved explanatory memorandum-
that was a major suggestion of the Green paper-
which would impose an additional load on top of the heavy burden Parliamentarians and Parliamentary Counsel already carry;
if, as the proposals in the Discussion Paper indicated, the new style memorandum was to be used only in association with some selected statutes, its scope would be very limited;

there was a case, however, supported by the authors of the papers and by a number of commentators and speakers, for action by the Parliament giving the Courts a judicial discretion to look beyond the four corners of the Statute when it seems appropriate to do so;

It is that conclusion, reported by Sir Anthony Mason and supported by Mr Justice Mason himself, which is the basis of the proposal in the Bill which is before us this morning. The Bill itself may go a little wider in the type of extrinsic material which may be looked at than was proposed by the people who attended the seminar. The most serious and concrete suggestion which was put to the seminar was one which to some extent I had floated-that perhaps Parliament should append a specially prepared explanatory memorandum to the Bill. The memorandum would then become physically a part of the Act and would be referred to by courts in interpreting the statute. For various reasons that suggestion did not find great favour at the seminar.

Having thought about the matter and listened to what people have had to say about it over quite a period, I believe that the approach taken in this legislation is the course to be preferred. Certainly at present it is more favoured than the more specific proposal made in the Green Paper which I commissioned. Nevertheless, this matter is in a state of flux, a state of development. I hope that the suggestion for a specially prepared explanatory memorandum will be given a go in a statute to see how it works out.

As I said, I believe this is all part of an ongoing experiment which will take some considerable time. It is very consistent with the whole development of our legal system. As I said when I opened the seminar last February:
This Symposium is neither the beginning nor the end of the process of rethinking and reforming the principles of statutory interpretation, but it is a most important step in that process.

Likewise, this legislation is neither the beginning nor the end of the process, but it certainly is another very important step in that development. It is pleasing to note that judges themselves are now openly referring to extrinsic material. But there is a certain hesitancy, one might say a coyness, on the part of judges in referring to this material, because in fact, under principles of statutory interpretation that have been laid down, they are not supposed to do so. As I said, they have been changing those rules, as they are entitled to do. This indication from Parliament is not mandatory; but it is an indication to them that they can be a little bolder than they have been in the past. I think that process will develop and should be encouraged by the Parliament.

I come back to the context in which this whole subject should be considered. It should be considered in the context of the problem of reforming the law. That is very much an ongoing process. In recent decades the dominance of Parliament in that process has come to a stage where it can no longer cope with the problem. I would hope that there would be less legislation in the future and more legislation in a general form so that courts would be able to apply it case by case. There is no reason why we should not be able to rely on the judges to perform what has been an historic process by them in developing the common law over centuries.

The next step probably is to persuade the parliamentary draftsmen that they do not need to dot every 'i' and cross every 't' in the legislation that they draft for our consideration. As I said, there is no way in the world that members of parliament can cope with legislation in that detail, understand it, or have more than a glimmer of understanding of the general process of it. This is a major problem facing not only judges, governments and parliamentary counsel, but also this chamber and the other place. We have to make up our minds about that subject as well. We should be promoting debate and consideration of it. I quote again from what I said in opening the seminar, for I adopt it. I do not think this morning I could better what I said on that occasion.
Judges should become bolder in applying both the principles of the common law and guidelines laid down by the Parliament.
Hopefully Parliament might be persuaded to give a greater role to the judges if it knew that they would accept the challenge. The importance of our present exercise--
this was said at a symposium but this is a current exercise-

Is that, with a purposive approach and better aids to interpretation, Parliament may be encouraged to reduce the size and complexity of legislation. It could itself do a better job by concentrating on the major issues of reform and the principles to be followed rather than attempting to provide the detail as well.

The Opposition supports the measure. I cannot express the various degrees of enthusiasm of various members of the Opposition, but I conclude by saying that I support it enthusiastically on a personal basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose one of the growing dangers of democracy is the greater incidence of judge-made laws. This has been seen in recent cases, particularly the dams case where the judges rewrote the Constitution without the Parliament having made any recommendations for constitutional changes to the people, and in a manner which was beyond the normal conception of the Australian people of what the Constitution meant. TALK.START.PARA: —They are not all matters approved by the Parliament.

—No, I said much less damage; I was putting the ideal first. Of course they are not matters approved. —The Attorney-General is a lawyer and I am not. —I will give some aids to your interpretations in a moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish in this debate also to address proposed section 15AB of the Acts Interpretation Act, which deals with the use of extrinsic material in the interpretation of an Act of Parliament. I would describe this amendment as a significant reform. It might be said that really it is only legislatively prescribing what judges are already doing, but I think it is relevant to note that they are not all doing that. There is still considerable difference of opinion between judges as to the extent to which they should take into account extrinsic materials and, if so, what extrinsic materials. The position is now one of some uncertainty and I believe, therefore, it is opportune for the legislature to act. The alternatives appear to me to be to restrict legislatively the use of extrinsic materials or to indicate legislatively to the court which of such materials we-those who pass laws- believe judges should take into account in their interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has by this provision gone towards the more flexible approach. I think it is fair to say that that has been the trend. When I studied law some 20 years ago I understood that one applied a literal rule where the provision was clear and unambiguous and where it was ambiguous one applied the mischief rule, which had its history in a resolution of the barons of the exchequer as far back as 1584. The courts have tended over the last few decades to look more towards the purpose of the Parliament, and that is something that I believe we should applaud. It might be said that there should be rarely any difficulty, that we should pass laws in clear and precise terms and that the words should reflect the meaning we intend. However, I think the ever-increasing number of cases concerned with statutory interpretation suggests that such is not the case.

There are several points to make in that regard. These matters may reflect the ever growing mass of legislation passed by this and other Parliaments in Australia. This point was emphasised by Senator Durack in his speech this morning. The mass and volume of legislation, regulations, rules, and so on, are becoming matters of real concern to the administration of justice and of major concern to those who have to administer and interpret the law and deal with it in their everyday affairs. It is a matter we must address. It has been said for a long time that that is the case. I remember seeing a Liberal Party advertisement that appeared in the year I was born, in 1946, to the effect that there was too much regulation in this country and that something should be done about it. The position has changed markedly since then towards a much greater volume of legislation and regulatory restriction.

The present situation might reflect poor drafting. Certainly some Bills presented to this Parliament are not well drafted. I do not entirely find fault with the parliamentary draftsmen whose task in many ways is the most difficult of all those who play a role in the production, passing and interpretation of legislation. In part, it reflects the fact that there always seems to be a degree of urgency when Bills come before Parliament, often urgency that does not really exist. Many amendments in such circumstances are taken on the run. For a whole series of reasons, great pressure is constantly put on parliamentary draftsmen. Consequently, their work is not always to the standard that they themselves would desire. Nevertheless, after years of training in tax law, I still find incomprehensible some of the provisions in that field that are passed in this Parliament. That is also the view of practitioners in the tax field. One has only to take as an example the first bottom of the harbour legislation last year. It is a good example as it was one of the few Bills that was studied in depth by Parliament. When Parliament does so it finds that the drafting difficulty is obvious.

The ever-increasing number of cases that go to the courts for statutory interpretation may well be a reflection of the fact that the Senate is not doing its job well enough. It can be fairly said that Parliament should not pass legislation that is not understood by parliamentarians. This raises the question whether the Senate committee system works well enough and whether Senate committees should have the role not only of examining matters of principle but also of drafting to ensure that what goes through Parliament is drafted in the best possible terms.

I recently saw a cartoon that appeared in a paper entitled 'Statutory Interpretation: Extrinsic Aid' put down by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) last October. The cartoon appeared in 1955 and showed eight elderly, crusty-looking, bald-headed gentlemen, senators, in a Senate committee room, four smoking cigars. The chairman, no doubt the 1955 equivalent of Senator Tate, said in the cartoon: 'Must we concern ourselves with the meaning of the Bills we pass? I understand it is the duty of the Supreme Court to interpret them'. Of course, parliamentarians must concern themselves with the meaning of the legislation they pass. That is what this place is all about. It is a responsibility we must continually bear in mind. Therefore, we must not pass legislation we do not understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you trying to tell me that most people in this place read the legislation?

—I was about to make that point, Senator Haines. Somebody asked me why so many amendments had been made to last year's Sex Discrimination Bill. I suggested the answer was that parliamentarians had read the Bill. I suspect a similar situation would occur if the same degree of attention were given to all legislation that passes through Parliament. Obviously individual parliamentarians will not have that time. However, the system can be developed whereby mechanisms can be used to assist parliamentarians in that regard. I mentioned a further development of the Senate committee system in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: My fourth point is that the increasing number of cases appearing before the court for statutory interpretation might also reflect a conscious decision by the Parliament to use general words. I think there has been a movement in that direction and it causes me some concern. If I correctly understood what Senator Durack said earlier, I disagree with it. It is certainly our responsibility to deal with matters of principle, but it is also our responsibility to deal with matters of detail. We should be reluctant to use general words when it is possible to be specific. I notice from the symposium that Mr Justice Murphy was one--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about section 92?
—I suppose that is the most broad and general example of all. Perhaps it has led to many of the problems.
—If every other part of the community can manage in English and doesn't have to use lawspeak, why can't pieces of legislation cover adequately their contents by using general language?

—It depends, I suppose, on what is meant by general language. I think one of the much quoted examples relates to workmen's compensation legislation that provides financial support for those who are injured in accidents arising out of their employment. One might say that that is written in general language that people understand, but the interpretation of the courts has given it meanings that would never have been contemplated by any parliament. I am suggesting that we should therefore be cautious in using words, general language, that would enable the courts to interpret our meaning in many different ways.
—Are you supporting the use of extrinsic aids?

—I am supporting the use of extrinsic aids. The question I am addressing myself to is why there is an ever increasing volume of cases before the courts on questions of interpretation of what we enact in this place.
—Too many lawyers?

—I am suggesting that one of the reasons for that is the trend towards the use of general language, a trend which was applauded by Mr Justice Murphy in the symposium to which the former Attorney-General referred. I am one who does not agree with that. I believe that we should be clear and precise wherever possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The fifth and final reason I think so many cases are appearing is that insufficient attention has been given to legislation because governments, whatever their colour, seem to regard the matters that they have before this place of great urgency when in most cases that urgency simply does not exist. In other words, matters should be given more careful attention. If we were allowed sufficient time I am sure that a better result would occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —As in the Judiciary Bill?

—The Judiciary Amendment Bill yesterday was a classic example. There was no urgency in that. I am disappointed that the Senate was not prepared to allow its committee system to examine that Bill in greater detail. I am sure that the ultimate result would have been more beneficial to the people of Australia.
—What happened to the Liberal's cry that governments are elected to govern and should not be interfered with by the Senate?
—Wasn't it bulldozed through by the Democrats?

—I would have thought that was one case in which the Democrats would have supported a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I was particularly concerned with the argument that because lawyers have different views on what appeals should lie of right to the High Court there was no need to go to the Committee. I had a lot of trouble in understanding that argument, but it was put by the Democrats on that occasion . I am sure that the committee system would have produced a better result. There is need for action at this level to reduce the occasions of need for the courts to interpret our legislation. Nevertheless, we should address the way we want the court to carry out its interpreting function; in other words, the guidelines we give to the court. The trend of this legislation is towards saying: 'We want an interpretation consistent with the meaning we intended'. I believe that is good.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation has come at the end of a long reform process. I think it is important that credit be given where it is due. For the first three steps of that process credit must be given to the former Government and the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack. I refer to the reform of 1981, the effect of which was to confirm that in interpreting provisions regard should be had to the object and purpose underlying the Act in question. Then there was the policy discussion paper of the former Attorney-General that was put down in October 1982, which further developed the debate in a helpful and constructive way. There was then the very fine symposium on statutory interpretation held in Canberra on 5 February 1983. I commend to all honourable senators the document put out by that symposium. In fact, I commend it to all lawyers. It was obviously a most productive exercise. Of course, I commend also the current Attorney-General, who has come into office and is proceeding to implement so much of what has gone before in this reform process.

Having decided that in certain circumstances we think the court should look at extrinsic aids to assist in determining the purpose and objective of the Parliament, the question is: What aids? Should they be unlimited or should they be specified? The Attorney-General has really backed both horses. He has made the list unlimited but has given guidelines, particularly as to those extrinsic aids that the court might consider. I support the notion of an unlimited list because it appears to me that it is impossible to say, short of the circumstances of a particular case, that one piece of information will be more helpful than another.

I reflect very briefly on just a couple of difficulties. One that was mentioned in some depth in the symposium considerations is that of the explanatory memorandum, which of course is determined by the Parliament. We must be wary of a situation in which the court finds that it is having to interpret two documents. Nevertheless, I concede that on some occasions that explanatory memorandum which is before the legislators at the time they consider a Bill might nevertheless give some indication of what the Parliament intended and, therefore, in some circumstances it will be helpful. With regard to considerations of the Hansard, Lord Wilberforce was not in favour. He said:
It seems to me quite reasonable to regard a report of a Commission, laid before Parliament as a whole, and drafted by experts, more favourably than uncoordinated speeches by individual legislators.

No doubt on some occasions that might be so, but in my respectful opinion often the court might find the second reading speech of a Minister less helpful. Certainly on occasions I have found it less helpful and certainly on occasions commission reports can be particularly unhelpful, but there will be occasions when they are of assistance in the same way that there will be occasions when the Hansard clearly gives an indication as to the intention of the Parliament. Therefore, I believe that the court in such circumstances should be free to use it for that purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't go past the second reading speech of the Minister though, would you? There are many cases in which the senators themselves put their interpretations and their confusion upon the intention.

—Yes, I would go past the second reading speech. Laws are passed by the Parliament, not by the Government. Therefore, I would take into account what is said by senators and members of the House of Representatives in certain circumstances.
—But the vote is not necessarily a reflection of their views.

—That is right, and at times there will be contradictory expressions. But what is being looked for are aids to interpretation. Obviously if there are a number of contradictory expressions, that will not be helpful aid . But in some circumstances I can imagine that it could be particulary helpful. I am suggesting that the court should be free to use such aids in circumstances that it finds helpful. I recognise the views expressed in yesterday's Australian , which I think we must reflect upon in this debate because they call for an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The article that appeared in that newspaper yesterday suggested great concern by the legal profession over these proposed amendments. It suggested that the Victorian Bar Association claims the move will create massive uncertainty in the law and have the effect of prolonging litigation due to extended argument over the meanings of words. It is said that one Queen's counsel, who was not named, was of the view that the provision would add to, rather than solve, ambiguity and obscurity in the normal wording of Acts. Such expressions must cause us to reflect upon what we are doing.

Having considered the matter at length, I disagree with the views that were put in that newspaper report. I certainly agree that in the case of a legislative provision that is ambiguous or obscure, or where its results are absurd or unreasonable, the court should be able to refer to whatever extrinisic aids it wishes to give the meaning to it which Parliament intended. I therefore fail to see how, in the case of, say, ambiguous provisions, these provisions can create massive uncertainty in the law. The massive uncertainty has its root in the unclear, ambiguous, obscure or unreasonable wording of the legislation. So I can only suspect that, in relation to that part of the provision, those who offered the opinion which was expressed in yesterday's Australian have not read the constructive views that were put to the syposium to which I have referred, and have not given the matter the careful consideration that it deserves.

I was more concerned with the first part of the provision, proposed section 15AB (1) (a), which legitimises the use of extrinsic aids to confirm that the meaning of the provision is the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of the provision taking into account its context in the Act and the purpose or object underlying the Act. I had to ask myself why, if the ordinary meaning is apparent , it is necessary to refer to extrinsic aids to confirm the provision. On reading the symposium speeches I particularly noted the very wise words of Mr Charles Comans, QC, a former First Parliamentary Counsel, who reminded me, as appears at page 26 of the symposium report, that such a provision is of value, saying:
Because you don't know whether the statute is clear until the court gives its judgment, and . . . you have two parties, each saying the statute is clear but both saying it means something different.

That reminded me of the fact that in most cases concerning statutory interpretation counsel go to the court and each side says that the words are clear and unambiguous, but each says that in applying a common, sensible interpretation he comes to a totally different and contrary conclusion. That is why I have decided, on balance, that it is wise to include a provision that allows the court in some circumstances to take into account extrinsic evidence to confirm the meaning of the ordinary provison conveyed in the text.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will this Bill do to Barwick's interpretation of the taxation Act? What would have been in place then?

—That is a very wide question, Senator Crichton-Browne. It should receive further detailed and careful attention. In conclusion, I believe that in the area of confirming the ordinary meaning there are some arguments to the contrary. It is a question of balance, and on balance I have come down in favour of the provisions of the Act. However, I refer to one part of the comments of a former senator, Mr Justice Murphy, to the symposium when, at page 40, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In our system, we should rely on extrinsic material as little as possible. It is common sense that those who have to use an enactment should be able, as far as possible, to find what they are supposed to do, or not do, from reading that enactment.

I think in that case they are wise words. They should be the first approach to questions of statutory interpretation. They should be what we bear in mind when we pass legislation in this place. Nevertheless, that will be insufficient in some cases, we have to concede that. Therefore the need for this Act arises; the need to look to the way in which the court can best give the interpretation that we intended. Therefore I believe that the use of extrinsic aids can be helpful in some circumstances in reaching that conclusion. I therefore commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Senate for the broad bipartisan support which has been given to this measure, the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1984, albeit not entirely without qualification in some instances, especially so far as Senator Harradine is concerned. Before saying just a few quick things about the centrepiece of the legislation, which is proposed new section 15AB dealing with extrinsic aids to the interpretation of statutes, might I for the record quickly correct a misleading statement that was contained in one point in the second reading speech. In relation to the provisions governing attainment of age-proposed new section 25E, which has nothing to do with the matters that have been engendering controversy in this debate-it was said by me in the second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: A provision along these lines has already been included in the Superannuation Act 1976.

By 'these lines' I was referring to a new provision to remove the rather mediaeval notion that a person attains a particular age at the first moment of the day immediately before the anniversary of his birth, rather than actually on his birthday. In fact that is wrong. The Superannuation Act does not contain a provision of that kind. The difficulty was that the obscurity of its drafting led my advisers to think that it did. I think the Superannuation Act is a classic example of the kind of legislation that needs all the help it can get when it comes to its interpretation by the courts or anyone else.

Turning to the question of extrinsic aids, I am pleased to note that there has been a general recognition around the chamber that on many occasions courts need to look beyond the strict terms of legislation if they are in fact to be able to discover with any degree of confidence what the Act means, or more particularly, perhaps, what the begetters of the Act would have wanted it to mean had they been confronted with a particular set of circumstances in facing the later interpreter.

There has been a general acceptance, it seems to me, of the validity and utility of setting out, as permissible aids to interpretation, the material that is listed in sub-section (2) of the proposed new section 15AB. I think there has been, however, insufficient attention given in the debate, particularly to those who are critical of the width of the range of material that would be now accessible, to the threshold hurdle requirement that is set out in sub-section ( 1) of the proposed new section 15AB, and also the further qualification that is contained in sub-section (3).

I remind the Senate that the only circumstances in which the extrinsic material identified in sub-section (2) can properly be looked at by the courts, if sub- section (1) is to have any force, are twofold. There are only two such circumstances. The first is where consideration is designed:
(a) to confirm that the meaning of the provision is the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of the provision taking into account its context . . . and the purpose or object underlying the Act--
That is the first context in which one would look to extrinsic aids. The second context is in accordance with proposed section 15AB paragraph (1) (b):
to determine the meaning of the provision when-
(i) the provision is ambiguous or obscure; or
(ii) the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text . . . leads to a result that is manifestly absurd or unreasonable.

The significance of that threshold hurdle that has to be jumped before we get into the water of sub-clause (2) has perhaps been a little understated in the course of the debate, as I indicated by way of interjection on Senator Harradine . The other thing that perhaps has been understated is the further qualification in sub-clause (3), which says that in determining whether consideration should be given to the extrinsic material in accordance with the threshold requirements in sub-clause (1), or in considering the weight to be given to any such material , regard shall be had . . . to two other things:

(a) the desirability of persons being able to rely on the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of the provision taking into account its context . . . and the purpose or object underlying the Act; and
(b) the need to avoid prolonging legal or other proceedings without compensating advantage.

There is a real point to the notion that courts, and more particularly perhaps those advising clients, ought to be able to rely reasonably confidently on material readily to hand when they are interpreting legislation rather than necessarily in every instance having to go to a library-something which may be very difficult indeed for a practitioner in the bush or the outer suburbs. The force and utility of sub-clause (3) was well acknowledged by Lord Wilberforce, who has played such a prominent part in our deliberations here in developing this notion. I asked him to comment on the final draft of the Bill as it had emerged and, in a letter of 21 March, he said:
Naturally, I am very pleased that you have been able to go so far along the path designated by the Symposium.
That was a reference to the Symposium on Statutory Interpretation organised by Senator Durack and held here early last year. Lord Wilberforce went on:
I like, particularly, subsection (3) of the new section 15AB.
That is very high judicial endorsement indeed for the approach here adopted from one of the most respected jurists in the common law world. I believe that ought to be acknowledged.

The final thing I have to say concerns the independence of the judiciary. I do not think any challenges to this legislative strategy based on that idea really have much foundation. As I said in my second reading speech, section 15AB does its job:
. . . in a way that respects the independence of the judiciary. Judges are neither required to nor prohibited from looking at any materials.

All that is happening here is that the Parliament is endeavouring to give a clear lead to the courts as to the way in which extrinsic materials can best be used-extrinsic materials which often feature in judicial interpretation at the moment-without, as I said, imposing undue burdens on the users of the legislation or the legal system generally. This is a very important measure; its significance ought to be in no way underestimated by the brevity of this debate. I commend it to the Senate and hope it will have a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 6, clause 13, sub-clause (1), proposed paragraph 25B (1) (a), line 19, leave out ',in any industrial agreement', insert 'or any industrial agreement, in any other order (whether executive, judicial or otherwise)'.
(2) Page 7, clause 13, sub-clause (1), proposed section 25D, line 7, after ' decision', insert ', whether the expression ''reasons'', ''grounds'' or any other expression is used,'.

That amendment will remove any doubt that the provision concerned includes court orders. The second amendment is to make it clear that the provisions concerned extend to a legislative provision requiring a statement of the grounds for the decision to be furnished in the decision. They are purely technical matters, the subject of oversight in the early draft. I understand there is no controversy about them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a general question with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) about future consideration of improving methods of statutory interpretation and of giving greater substance to the purpose of approach. On reflection I think we are better to take the approach of proposed section 15AB rather than the approach that I originally suggested of a specially prepared explanatory memorandum. I still believe that that approach could be of long term benefit and a solution to the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested in Senator Hill's continuing concern about the nature of legislation and how far one can, in fact, go along the lines that I mentioned of general terms only. The idea of a specially prepared explanatory memorandum being adopted by the Parliament does satisfy the concerns of those members of parliament who wonder how far the courts will go without the confines of parliamentary approval and about the extent to which we ought to have general instead of specific terms. I think they are very reasonable concerns. It seems to me that an explanatory memorandum appended to a Bill and approved by the Parliament satisfies those two concerns. I would not like to see this particular step being regarded as the end of the road and I wonder what the Attorney- General has in mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the force of Senator Durack's comments and I do so particularly against the background of knowing how much thought and consideration he has personally given this issue over the last few years. I treat anything he says in this area, if not always in some others, with a great deal of respect. In fact I am quite sympathetic to the idea of developing more extensive explanatory memorandums as the primary vehicle through which additional or supplementary material can be conveyed to the courts simply because, more than anything else, of the accessibility argument so far as legal advisers and others are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: There are examples of this kind of approach to the drafting of explanatory memorandums now in the pipeline. The best example I can think of is the explanatory memorandum we are now writing for the Australian Bill of Rights which may not see public light for some considerable time. It is an example of a very discursive explanatory memorandum designed to give a great deal of guidance to the courts as to what is intended by some rather innovative drafting. The explanatory memorandums as they are presently drafted are remarkably useless documents in the sense that they often merely repeat, very often in language just as obscure to the layman as the original legal text, stuff which is perfectly apparent from the face of the Bill rather than adding in any way to one's comprehension of it.

Where I have reservations and where I think I disagree with Senator Durack at the moment, although I will certainly give it more thought, is in the idea of Parliament formally endorsing the explanatory memorandum. It seems to me that one then gets into an almost infinite regress situation where if Parliament is endorsing it, it will want to satisfy itself about every word in it and we will almost have the potential for Committee stage debates on the text of the explanatory memorandum. I am not sure that we have fully thought our way through the implications of that development. Certainly it is something I am happy to keep very much in the forefront of my mind as experience develops in relation to this particular legislation and I look forward to continuing constructive bipartisan consultations in doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I am pleased that he is not looking at this as being the end of the road or the final solution. I suggest that he take the opportunity to experiment with a document of this kind in a Bill which is, perhaps, not too controversial but certainly one that we are likely to get before us this year and is not obviously being put off until after the next election to save the Government any embarrassment. Although the Bill of Rights might be a suitable vehicle, it will certainly be controversial. I am suggesting that the Attorney- General do this as an experiment in a pretty non-controversial area. We could put to the test the concern, which I agree is real, that Parliament will be diverted to the explanatory memorandum rather than to the Bill, and that there will be debate about that and so on. I think the whole matter ought to be put to the test in some experimental way at an early opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take that suggestion on board.
