DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE CONDUCT OF A JUDGE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received letters from the Leader of the Government, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and the Leader of the Australian Democrats nominating Senators Bolkus, Crowley, Tate, Durack, Lewis and Chipp to be members of the Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senators Bolkus, Chipp, Crowley, Durack, Lewis and Tate, having been duly nominated in accordance with the resolution of the Senate dated 28 March 1984, be appointed as members of the Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Attorney- General from making a statement on the content and authenticity of the 'National Times' article 'Australia's New Defence Strategy' published today, 30 March 1984 , and on the steps taken by the Government to keep the document secure; and as would prevent a debate on the issue.

I move that motion in accordance with standing order 448. The National Times features what purports to be a leaked document from the Government on the Government's posture on defence. The article is shocking. I do not know to what extent it is accurate, but it is a shocking article for what it contains. Assuming that the article is true, one would have thought that the Australian Labor Party's ditching of its anti-uranium policy, among other policies, was enough hypocrisy and deceit from one government. What this document makes clear is that the past deceit is child's play compared with the activity going on behind the scenes at the moment. The Hawke Government, elected with an aura of hope and reform, is now acting out policies akin to the most rabid, right wing warmongers and sabre rattlers of the Reagan Administration. That is why I believe this matter to be so urgent as to come within the ambit of standing order 448.

I will give some reasons why it is urgent. Allegedly, one aspect of the document is that Australia should be in a position to develop nuclear weapons as quickly as any of its neighbours that look like doing so. To quote from the alleged document, we should be able 'to ensure that the lead time for Australia could be matched to developments in other countries should the Government so decide'. That simply means, in the jargon of the defence strategists, that we have, or should have, the materials on the shelf to make nuclear weapons and that all we have to do is put them together, which is exactly the position that countries such as Israel seem to adopt.
What allows this matter to come under the standing order 448 is a statement in the National Times-I agree that it is not supported by evidence-which states:
The Government has fully supported the document, which is called the Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy.
If I were a member of the Labor Party I would demand that a Caucus meeting be held at lunchtime today and I would ask how much of the article is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which faction?

—I think each of the three factions would be vitally interested in the subject. In fact, we are not talking about some penny-ante issue; we are talking about the defence and the future of this country. The future of the planet is discussed in the paper. That is why it has become so urgent. I believe that the Senate has a right to know whether the Government endorses these outrageous propositions.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement is made that the ANZUS treaty is not likely to be of use in a potentially troublesome situation such as a conflict with Indonesia. Is that the Government's view? The Senate needs to be told. It is stated that international issues should be seen in terms of United States-Soviet rivalry. Is that the Government's position? The paper claims that the Soviets have nuclear superiority over the United States of America which could lead to a dangerous lack of political will by the United States. Inherent in that view is the monstrous concept that we should encourage the United States to build more nuclear weapons. That is what that means. That is what those creatures in the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs are planning and plotting in a secret document and that is what, allegedly, members of the Labor Government have embraced as their policy. They are encouraging the United States to build more nuclear weapons; otherwise the United States might lose the political will to fight the Soviets. Yet, this Government has pressed for disarmament initiatives. What hypocrisy! What absolute and total hypocrisy! At least the Liberal Government came out with its defence and foreign policies, much as I disagreed with them, and had the honesty to say: 'That is our policy, there it is'. But this mob, which has appointed an Ambassador for Disarmament, is, at the same time, encouraging the United States to build more nuclear weapons. I find that kind of hypocrisy mind-boggling. That is why I believed, as soon as this article in the National Times hit the deck, that it had to be debated in this place. I hope that the Government will agree to the suspension of Standing Orders so that we can debate the matter. I point out to the Government that it might find itself in an invidious position and that it might need a leader with 78 per cent popularity to get away with this.

Assuming that the Opposition will support this motion, it will be carried. But because I did not have the foresight to have a contingent notice of motion placed on the Notice Paper, even if we win the vote the Government will refuse to debate the issue today. As far as I and, I hope, the Opposition are concerned , we will not be thwarted by technicalities such as that. I give notice to the Government that if that happens I will give notice today that I will do the same thing on Monday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable senator to provide the Chair with a copy of his motion.

—Yes, Mr President. I apologise for not doing so earlier, but we ran out of time this morning. The document in question allegedly states that ' United States bases in Australia are nuclear targets but the risks are worth it' . I believe the Senate and the people of Australia are entitled to know whether the Government embraces and accepts that attitude. The Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, who represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in this place, gave me answers which were directly contrary to this question only a few months ago. It is always my practice with questions on foreign affairs to give the Attorney-General notice of the question. I do that so I can get a good answer from him, not one off the cuff. That gives him the opportunity, before Question Time, to seek the official attitude from the Department of Foreign Affairs. On several occasions I asked him whether Pine Gap, Nurrungar, Perth and other places were nuclear targets. The only answer I have received from the Department of Foreign Affairs is that only North West Cape is a nuclear target. Yet apparently this document says 'the United States bases in Australia are nuclear targets'. Then there is this most outrageous statement 'but the risks are worth it'. Which bases does the Government believe are nuclear targets? Do not the people of Western Australia and South Australia at least deserve to know whether bases in their States are regarded by the Government as nuclear targets? What sort of an open government do we have when it says: 'There are United States bases in Australia which are nuclear targets, but we are not going to tell the people who live in those States which bases we regard as nuclear targets'. The Government will not allow debate on this issue in the Parliament.
—How do you know?
—Because you told me so.
—That was a different motion. You have not told me the terms of your new motion.
—That was at a different time of day. Mr President, with your indulgence, so that we can end this humbug, I ask the Attorney-General whether he intends to agree to this motion.
—Yes, because this is a different motion. I am happy to make a ministerial statement. You wanted a general debate on the whole thing which is premature.

—The Attorney-General can snigger, as is his want. No doubt after this he will have a Press conference, as is his want. He seems to love having Press conferences at which he backgrounds journalists off the record. I showed him the motion half an hour ago and was told that the Government would oppose it . If the Government intends to accept it there is no point in my continuing with the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

—In light of the interjection from the Government indicating that it will support this motion , I will not speak at any length at this stage. I wish to acknowledge the inclusion by the Australian Democrats of the words which we requested and which expand the original motion. We sought the inclusion of the words 'and on the steps taken by the Government to keep the document secure'. This is a very significant matter, not merely because of the content of the document which has been published by the National Times. It is also a matter of very considerable significance because this is merely the latest in a series of leaks from the Government which go to the security of Australia. It is the Opposition's view that the Parliament should be concerned not merely about whether the document is accurate and whether it conflicts with the ostensible policy of the Government and of the Australian Labor Party; we also are deeply concerned that so significant a document apparently has been leaked in this way. We support the motion moved by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp. We look to the Government to make the speediest possible and the fullest possible disclosure to this Parliament on the matters on which information is sought in the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated, the Government will not oppose this motion despite the fact that we could, as the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, has said, prevent the suspension of the Standing Orders. I wish to make a couple of points . The first is that quite clearly the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, who represents the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) in this place, cannot make a detailed reply this morning on the steps taken by the Government to keep the document secure. I am sure that no one would reasonably expect him to do so. Of course, we will be taking steps to address that matter, but to expect Senator Evans to make a detailed reply on that is wrong. Secondly, I put it to Senator Chipp and others that it would not be possible to have a comprehensive debate on a subject of such importance which has really just come to light. Senator Evans intended to make a statement to this chamber. He will now make that statement as a result of the motion. I expect that the statement is as detailed as it can be now and any response should await proper detailed examination of the whole affair. As I say, the Government will not oppose the motion to suspend Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement which I now make on behalf of the Government goes directly to the question of the content and authenticity of the National Times article and although short is as much as the Government proposes to say on the subject. As has been indicated, the statement will not address the steps taken by the Government to keep the document in issue secure, but I will certainly undertake to ensure that the Government gives consideration to some appropriate statement that can be made in due course on that subject matter. What I am able to say is this: The Government will neither confirm nor deny the accuracy of the purported extracts from the document 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy 1983' published in the National Times yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that a document of that title was considered by Cabinet last year , it was simply endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies. It is not a policy document but to the extent that any policy prescriptions were contained in it these were not specifically endorsed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they generally endorsed?

—Not generally endorsed except as a guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies. The National Times article is totally mischievous and misleading on the particular question of nuclear capability. I can state categorically that the Government has never made any decision to acquire or develop a nuclear capability, whether in the short, medium or long term, or in response to any particular contingency. Nor has the Cabinet or any Cabinet Committee even discussed the question.

SPEECH.PARA: The commitment of the Australian Government, like its predecessors, to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is complete and unequivocal. That treaty creates a permanent and binding obligation on Australia not to develop or acquire nuclear weapons. We will not only honour that obligation, but support all efforts to strengthen its application. I present the following paper:
Document entitled 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy 1983': Publication in National Times'-Ministerial Statement, 30 March 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

We have been given, as the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) described it, a short statement, and that is a matter about which we might not complain, given the relatively short notice that the Attorney has had about this matter. But we certainly do complain about the statement of the Attorney-General that what he has said is as much as the Government proposes to say about this issue. I do not believe that the people of Australia, let alone the Parliament of Australia, are going to allow the Government to take the view that it can say as little as has just been said by the Attorney-General. This is a matter of very great seriousness which touches upon Australia's national security and some fundamental areas of policy which go to that national security.

We might be excused for regarding this as something which one would almost forgive a government, if it were the sort of mistake that was made about a minor issue of policy, if it were something that did not go to such substantial issues . We might be less condemnatory if it were the first example of this sort of leak from this Government. But, of course, it is not the first example of this sort of leak from this Government. Although the Government, we understand, told the United States of America that Mr Toohey's sources had been closed off, it is quite clear that Mr Toohey does have access to documents of a sort that certainly should not be falling off the backs of trucks in the way that it is clear documents are falling off the backs of trucks.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happened under your Government. What are you talking about?

—Let me remind the Senate, and in particular those honourable senators opposite who are now interjecting, that less than a year ago we had the first serious security leak from this Government, by Mr Young. Let me remind the Senate that complaints about what Mr Young did are not matters of opposition carping about this Government. They are matters that have been dealt with by a judicial inquiry, a royal commission established by this Government, which has made it quite clear that Mr Young was seriously at fault when, as a Minister of this Government, he breached the security requirements that were placed on him. Let me remind the Senate of what was said by the judge who was appointed by this Government to examine those matters. I refer to the report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, specifically to the report on terms of reference (c) of December 1983. The judge said in that case:

SPEECH.PARA: I am also of the view that the potential, rather than the actual, damage to the national security is what must be considered in determining impropriety.
In respect of Mr Young he said:
. . . there was, in my opinion, a real risk that significant damage could have resulted from the disclosures.
Later, talking about the potential consequences of the loose lips of Mr Young, he said:
In my opinion these potential consequences gave rise to a real danger of significant damage to national security.

He said it was relevant to consider the circumstances, but that whilst Mr Young was simply helping an old friend, that did not 'in my opinion, diminish what I regard as the impropriety of the disclosures'. I quote from a little later in the same paragraph:
I have concluded that, notwithstanding this short Ministerial experience, it should have been apparent to Mr Young that he should not make the disclosures.
A little later in the report he said:
. . . my conclusion is that the disclosures by Mr Young to Mr Walsh on 21 April 1983 were both unauthorised and improper.

Although Mr Young is now back in the Ministry and apparently now has the full approbation of this Government, I remind the Senate that on the findings of Mr Justice Hope there was a very significant breach of the security requirements placed on a Minister of this Government. Now we are being told by the Attorney- General that the statement that he gave us is as much as the Government proposes to say, on a matter which goes to our relations with the United States, on a matter which goes to our defence policy, a matter that goes to our attitude to nuclear arms and to possible breaches of obligations under the Treaty on the Non -Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. That is not a tenable position for the Government to adopt. It has greater responsibilities than that.

I suggest to the Government that it will be required by its own supporters and by the factions of the Left, Centre-Left and all the various groupings that make up the Government Party, to give some better explanations to the Caucus and to those factions than it has given to the Parliament today, and this Parliament is not going to be treated more cheaply than the Government will have to treat its own Caucus and its supporters. I give notice to the Government that we do not believe that the early and inadequate explanation which has been given by the Attorney-General is at all sufficient. In fact, the Attorney-General has followed the technique that he followed in respect of other issues that have been before this Parliament, with regard to the Age tapes. He said: 'Well, we do not authenticate this document'. He then went on to explain it in terms that make it quite clear that though the Government is not authenticating every word it is authenticating the fact that such a document exists, that such a document has been before the Cabinet, and most critically, that that document now represents the action plan on which officials of this Government are now required to work.

What the Attorney-General said was that the document that had been considered had been 'endorsed by way of guidance'. That is precisely the sort of suggestion that is made by the National Times:That this is a document which will provide a guidance for the officials who work on behalf of this Government in the development and the conduct of policies that are fundamental to the interests of this country. We cannot accept as satisfactory the very brief explanation given by the Attorney-General.

We sought, and the Australian Democrats agreed to include in their motion a reference to the fact that the Government should also advise us on the steps that have been taken to keep the document secure. As I have indicated already, this is not the first security breach by the Hawke Government.The fact is that the Hawke Government stands convicted by its own inquiry of a very significant breach of the requirements that are placed on the Government to defend national security. Now we are faced with some of what ought to be its most closely held documents being leaked to a national newspaper. I think the public is entitled to an explanation as to what security measures have been taken by the Government to try to protect this sort of material. We have had no explanation so far, but we do demand one.

The Opposition has had as little time as the Attorney-General had to examine the matters that have surfaced over the past few hours. Of course the Attorney- General had the advantage of having access to the documents at the time they were considered in Perth, and so on. We would say that the release of these documents indicates that there has been a serious national security leak of a kind that is, if anything, more serious than the leak that gave rise to the earlier royal commission. It is a matter that goes to our relationships with our nearest neighbours and our most powerful allies. It is an absolute absurdity to think that a few paragraphs is sufficient government response. This is a document which has the potential to damage Australia's relationships with its ANZUS allies and with the countries to our near north.

We would say that the actions of the Hawke Labor Government in foreign affairs have already damaged our relations internationally, and the fact that the document refers to the possible need for an independent nuclear deterrent is as good an example as one will get of the effects which Labor's foreign policy will have. We need to know the status of this document, though we have had some explanation of that from the Attorney-General; whether it has been endorsed by the Cabinet, as claimed by the National Times. It would appear to have been confirmed by the Attorney-General that it has been endorsed by way of guidance, and that it is in fact a relevant action document for senior public servants working for this Government. We need to know what action the Government is taking to investigate this very serious leak, and we need to know what action was taken before the leak occurred to prevent documents of this sort from being dealt with. It is quite clear many more copies of this document have been circulated than would be prudent. It would appear that the Government has been relatively cavalier in its handling of this material. This is further evidence of the Government's inability to keep secrets and shows its lack of proper concern for national security.

I am sure that the Senate will wish to have another opportunity to debate this matter when the Attorney-General reports back with the further details which have been sought by this motion and on which he has undertaken to make inquiries . On behalf of the Opposition, I express our profound concern at this latest example of Government incompetence, incompetence in dealing with national security and incompetence on the part of the Minister for Defence of this country, demonstrated as recently as yesterday when he did not even reply to the serious matters raised in the House of Representatives in a debate on a matter of public importance. I profess our profound dissatisfaction with the level of explanation given so far and say that we will demand a far better accounting in the national interest in the very near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The statement which has just been made by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is one of quite extraordinary importance and significance for two reasons. Perhaps even more significant than the revelations is the fact that the Minister's comments on them have added another dimension of significance and importance. While I agree with the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) that this matter must be the subject of further debate, it certainly does not need days, hours or weeks to make the decision that these matters are of grave importance to Australia. Indeed, this is something of a watershed in a view by the Government of this country on a matter of basic significance, perhaps a matter of life and death to the people of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The two reasons are these: The first, as mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition, is that a document of the title mentioned was considered by Cabinet last year. It was simply endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and the development of Australian defence policies; it is not a question of options but of guidance. That is a matter of enormous significance. It was not an options document that was put forward, which would perhaps allow every parameter to be investigated; one might see that as a reasonable thing for defence planners to do. But that is not the case. We have been told categorically by the Minister that the document was endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning which, of course, means all of our future conduct of defence, the materiel we intend to purchase and what we would do about nuclear weapons and about the development of Australia's defence policy. That is even more fundamental than the question of defence planning because, obviously, the policies are in association with and precede the planning.
The second point of major significance when associated with that is that the Minister, in the first sentence of the statement, said:
The Government will neither confirm nor deny the accuracy of the purported extract from the document 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy 1983' published in the National Times yesterday.

The key point is that the Government will not deny the accuracy of that document . It has seen it in the National Times. It is fairly detailed. I have read it myself. It has the appearance of authenticity and I do not think it is the sort of thing that anybody could feasibly or reasonably forge. I cannot see why anybody would want to do so, even if it were forged--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Hitler diaries?

—The Attorney-General mentions the Hitler diaries but I do not really believe that the degree of mischief exists in this society which would create a document of this detail. The point is that if indeed that had happened, surely the Government would have had time by now to have looked at it and to be in a position to confirm or deny these matters.
—They would not have hesitated; that is the point.

—I do not think they would have hesitated in those circumstances. Was there a document of that title? I ask the Attorney-General to say now by way of interjection whether that document was a fraud. Are substantial parts of it genuine? That is all that is important. It is bad enough as it stands. That is the second point-I note that the Minister does not interject-of why this is such a serious situation. We are justified in raising this matter now as a matter of urgency. It is not a matter that will take weeks and months to look at. We have had reviews of defence before and statements about it from the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes). There has been no hint that any of this material was being considered. We have had all sorts of pious statements in all areas from the Labor Government-about the Government's view on a nuclear free zone, about Papua New Guinea, about not wanting the proliferation of nuclear weapons and all sorts of other things. Now we are told that, in spite of those things having been said , here is a document which virtually is the guidelines for the future of the defence of this country. We have had no indication from the Government that it is prepared to deny that.

SPEECH.PARA: The implications of the document will send shock waves in many directions. Certainly that has been the effect so far on the Australian Democrats and I think it will be the effect on the public. I invite the Minister, as I raise these points from the National Times to deny them categorically. I ask the Attorney-General to do so by way of interjection. It is a good way of clearing up the matter.

I start with the idea that we ought to be looking at nuclear weapons. In view of the fact that documents of broad scope such as these are likely to be leaked because so many departments and individuals handle them and because it has been the experience of this Government and the previous one that documents of this sort are leaked, I think it very strange that this idea that we should be able to make nuclear weapons as fast as our neighbours and that we should keep our technical options open to do it would even have been canvassed at a policy level . I find that extraordinary. The only reason I could see that the Government would take the risk of doing that, which after all must be a provocative statement to our neighbours now that it has emerged, would be that the Government takes it seriously. If it did not take it seriously, surely it would not be so naive and innocent as to leave a time bomb like that sitting in the middle of a document that had every likelihood of being leaked.

What is the effect of that on our neighbours? That idea seems to us a completely unnecessary and mischievous statement. It could well make and probably already is making our neighbours feel that they might have an obligation to respond in a similar fashion. That is the terrible damage of that point. The effect could well be to create a mini-nuclear arms race in our region , with the most appalling consequences for the future. A government ought to understand what it should not say as much as what it should say. To have raised this matter at all in that area is a shocking thing and one which will be seen as shocking around the world. It is a shocking thing that we should come out with that sort of cynicism and say now-when we have no evidence whatsoever that any of our neighbours are interested in nuclear weapons; they do not even have nuclear power or anything else-that that is to be one of our options for the future. We are saying it now-not in five years or 10 years or when Indonesia or the Philippines has an enrichment plant or whatever; I am not saying that they will have but that at least might have given some cause for this statement.

Among the shock waves that come from this statement is the implication that we will keep available the technical means. That is the only way one can construe the comment that we have to look at the lead times for developing nuclear weapons and be prepared to do what our neighbours may do. I would like to ask whether that is correct. I have heard no interjection from the Government yet to deny any of these matters I have raised. SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that a document of that title was considered by Cabinet last year . . .

it was simply endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies.

The National Times article is totally mischievous and misleading on the particular question of nuclear capability.

and calls upon the Government to make a full statement as a matter of urgency on the content of and decisions taken by the Government on the document known as 'The Strategic Basis of Australia's Defence Policy 1983' and the steps taken by the Government to keep the document secure.

Add to the motion to take note of the statement the following words:

and calls upon the Government to make a full statement as a matter of urgency on the content of and decisions taken by the Government on the document known as 'The Strategic Basis of Australia's Defence Policy 1983' and the steps taken by the Government to keep the document secure.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to that, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has said that a document with that title was considered by Cabinet last year. Therefore, we know that such a document was considered by Cabinet last year. He said, nevertheless, that he will neither confirm nor deny a specific subject matter in the National Times. He went on to say something of profound significance:

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the next sentence, if you are looking for qualification.
—We have had in the last year from the Attorney-General a series of retreats that would make Napoleon's retreat from Moscow look like an amateur event.

—Time after time, day after day, in a lost cause, all he can do is interject and abuse. Today he comes before us with the same technique. He is again doing a Wran. SPEECH.PARA: I make the important point that nowhere has it been suggested that any part of the document that went before Cabinet was rejected in any way. The presumption is that the document as a whole, whatever its contents, was accepted for a specific purpose. It is no good saying that it was not for some particular policy. It was endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policy. Nothing could be more specific than that that document, whatever it is, viewed by the Australian people is to be accepted as being the basis on which the Government is to proceed in its defence planning and its policy. The important thing to know is this: Is this the document? Are these specifics in it, which were endorsed for guidance, for the purpose of review or not?

We had the experience with the tapes that day after day, week after week, we had to drag the Attorney-General screaming to the table, making admissions, contradicting himself the whole time, and finally, in a disgraceful attitude, being forced to admit that there was substance in what the public and the Opposition had been saying. If the Government does not face this matter squarely and with immediacy, day after day, week after week the Australian public will be taking this document seriatim, piece by piece, and demanding of the Government whether this was the substance adopted in terms of the statement today by way of guidance for the purpose of review of defence planning and the development of Australian defence policy. It must come out. It cannot be left like this. Are we to have the situation that all the external nations are to look at this and not know whether this is true or false, or are they to be told surreptitiously whether it is true or false?

The fact is that this document makes some serious assertions. It takes some hypotheses which suggest that certain of our neighbours could be our enemies. That is not a very happy situation to have published-a diplomatic gaffe of immense consequence. I wonder therefore what the Attorney-General would say now to this question of ministerial responsibility. I remind him that on 2 December he made it very clear in this chamber, in response to a question by me, that a Minister must take the responsibility for the consequences of his actions. I refer in this case to one Minister, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is not just the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) who is involved. It is a Cabinet submission by a committee of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Treasury and the Department of Defence, and ministerial responsibility for this must be the Prime Minister's. Last year he did articulate this principle:

. . . on no less an authority, as I invoked, of Mr Malcolm Fraser. Of course, it is a question of interpretation, in all the circumstances of a particular case, of what is a major blunder of real importance to Australia, and no doubt some anxious consideration will always be given--
Remember the word 'always'? It seemed to be a good idea at the time-
. . . to the proper application of that criterion by Ministers concerned. I find it quite intolerable, however, that we should be subjected to hypocrisy . . .

And so he went on. The situation is that he has made it clear that he accepts the principles laid down by Malcolm Fraser for ministerial responsibility. There has been a leak of major proportions. The public needs to know, for example, if there has been repetition of ministerial leaking. Unless a full revelation is to be made, are we to have another situation such as the one involving Mick Young and the breaches of security of the past? Has there been a conscious leaking in this regard? Can anyone now trust this Government at the security level? That is of enormous importance. It is not good enough for the Government simply to say that it will neither confirm nor deny.

This document raises an intriguing challenge. It would be fair to say that many of the major assessments in this document represent the assessments and the policies put forward by the Fraser Government over the period of seven years and which were unequivocally rejected by the Labor Party. Point after point in this assessment were points that had been asserted by the Liberal Government and rejected by the Labor Party. Are we now to say that we are seeing a redemption of conscience by the Labor Party? Is it now admitting that the assessments that were made over the years, which it rejected publicly and vociferously, are now correct? Is that fascinating situation coming before us? I must say that not all the assertions made in the document would have been acceptable to a Liberal Government. For example, I puzzle completely over a statement dealing with nuclear proliferation which says:
The spread of nuclear capabilities would not weaken the strategic predominance of the US and the USSR, and would have its effects primarily at the regional level.
Those who view the world scene and see that smaller nations by their aggressive actions have been able to alter the course of the world's peaceful pursuits will scarcely accept that.

This document, 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy', was in fact before the Cabinet. It was adopted in terms of guidance for its review of defence planning and its defence policies. The question now is this: Is the substance of these leaks as published in the National Times true or false? To that question the Government answers that it will neither confirm nor deny. The fact of the matter is that it is not a question of whether or not something illegally obtained by the Press should be rejected. Indeed, I remember that the Attorney-General, in a latter day redemption on his part, indicated that illegally obtained information can still be used in courts of law provided it can be supported. What is now needed is for this Government to come clean and simply tell the Australian public and the world outside whether this document, as printed, is correct or not. It is not good enough to leave it hanging in the air. The effect on our allies and on other nations in our region is very bad.

We have exposed all sorts of hypotheses as to which countries are our friends and enemies. We have nakedly trailed our thinking in the international domain and we now need to face up to the situation and say whether this document is correct or not. There is no way that this Government can escape that. It ought to know from the Jackson tapes and others that simply fighting a rearguard action will do it no good. In the end everything will come out, point by point. For example, the Attorney withheld information on the Jackson tapes and said he had had only 20 minutes reading of them. In the end, the consequences were shown to the public to be of great significance; so in the end, point by point everything in these extracts will also be analysed.

I make it abundantly clear that the extracts are of enormous significance. The fact that they have been leaked is one thing. That in itself is a reflection of an enormous kind on ministerial and Cabinet responsibility. Let the Government now look towards that question of ministerial responsibility. What Minister will take the blame for something that has gravely damaged Australia's credit in the world? Who will the Prime Minister put his finger on this time to take the blame ? I make the point that this is in fact profoundly a prime ministerial gaff of major consequence, whatever may be the role of the Minister for Defence in this. He, after all, is accident-prone enough to start with. What will happen to ministerial responsibility with respect to this matter? Will we have more and more leaks of top level security documents in this country? What will happen to satisfy the Australian people and the nations of the world of the truth or falsity of each of these things?

The subject matter of this document covers virtually a review of all the key security matters of the free world and the Iron Curtain countries. It is necessary to look at each of these matters so that Australia and the world can know whether these views were put forward by a Cabinet committee and whether this was the viewpoint of the three major departments listed. It is of tremendous importance that we know the answer to that question. If the answer is no, the allegations need to be denied. Failing any specific analyses of these extracts step by step, the Australian people and people outside could competently infer that in fact that committee did come to these conclusions and write these views; those views having been written down, the document was presented to the Cabinet which adopted it for the purposes which we now understand to be as follows-'guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies'. It is significant that in the Attorney-General's statement there was no qualification of that. He did not say that the document contained a number of postulates, a number of assertions, which the Cabinet rejected. That was not said. The implication was that the document itself--

TALK.START.PARA: —The next sentence of paragraph 2: 'It is not a policy document . . . not specifically endorsed'.

—The Attorney-General interjects that it was not a policy document. Let me make it clear that I am referring to assertions made in it and not denied, because if the assertions were not denied they would properly be used as 'guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies'. It is not a question of specific policies but of whether the assertions and conclusions made paragraph by paragraph through the document were accepted or rejected. I repeat: It will not be good enough in the future for the Government, facing a running trial of questions, to say, 'Oh, on that one we did not accept it'. The Attorney has said today that the general conclusions in the document were accepted for guidance. He said that it was simply endorsed by way of guidance. What was simply endorsed ? The document contains a series of conclusions and assertions. They were endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of policies. It is no good saying that the policies were not accepted if, in fact, the assertions and conclusions which pre-empt the policies , from which the policies should emerge, have been accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very grave situation. A document of a very serious character has been leaked. The previous leak by the Special Minister of State, Mr Young, was sufficient for a royal commission to be set up to look into it. This is of much more major importance. The consequence of the leak is far greater than the bar room or luncheon conversation of Mr Young on particular matters relating to a Russian diplomat. This touches all nations. It makes critical comments on a vast number of situations. First of all, what is to be done about ministerial responsibility? Who is to have this responsibility sheeted home? If nothing else , nobody can argue that a major leak has not occurred, and that leak has done great harm to Australia and its credit. Accepting that, and not needing to know one iota more of any information from the Government, a leak having occurred and it being of great gravity, what Minister is responsible and what is the Government going to do to enforce and to reinforce ministerial responsibility? Then, of course, there follows the step by step situation here. What is going to be done now to repair the damage that has been done on the international scene, damage that is of considerable significance?

This is a very serious matter indeed. It gets to the heart of the whole Cabinet . It gets to the full responsibility of the Prime Minister himself, who is the person with primary responsibility for the whole issue. The strategic survey is not the responsibility of one Minister, it is a collective responsibility of the Cabinet under the Prime Minister. The documents are not Defence Department documents any longer, they are documents that come from a committee set up by Cabinet and the security of them is the responsibility of the Prime Minister. I will be looking at how the Government faces up to this question of ministerial responsibility and the very serious breach of that responsibility.

I appeal to the Government not to attack this debate on the basis of its being purely a matter of the Opposition versus the Government and go on the defensive but rather to look at the serious allegations, if that is all we want to term them as, that have appeared in a national newspaper and meet the debate so that the implications for Australia and our own people are made clear. It will not go away by utterly and categorically denying something which is not in the article. It will not go away by the Government's saying that it refuses to confirm or deny it when it is doing precisely that now with other governments. It will not go away by saying that this is not a policy document but merely a document for the guidance of policy development. If it is such a document, in many instances it should not be. At least the previous Government had the wherewithal to say- and Mr Fraser said it-that Australia would not develop nuclear weapons. If any guidance has been given to make sure not that we are going to develop nuclear weapons but that we will have the technical capacity to do so if the Government should so decide, let us know that; let this Parliament know what this country is committed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just told you, in paragraph 3.

—The Attorney-General has not told me. Had he listened to what I have said he would know that I explained it very clearly. The allegation concerns ensuring that the lead time for Australia could be matched to developments in other countries should the Government so decide.
—Get up now, Attorney, and say you will never do it.
—I have said it already, in paragraphs 3 and 4. Look at it; it refers to a 'permanent and binding obligation'; we will 'honour that obligation'. Read the statement.

—I have read the statement and have said that giving guidance to bureaucrats to ensure that the lead time for Australia could be 'matched to the developments in other countries' should the Government so decide is completely compatible with 'has not made any decision' because it has been said that no decision has been made. They are compatible.
—Paragraph 4! You are profoundly disturbed.

—I raised paragraph 4 in the context of the other items and I got a denial from the Attorney-General. He then sought to withdraw that denial because, he said, he did not know to which paragraph I was referring. I went through paragraphs 1, 2, 3 and 4. I believe that what I have spelt out is true in terms of what the Attorney-General's statement says. It is no good the Attorney-General shaking his head; people not only in my party but also in his party and out in the electorate are concerned. They will not be satisfied with the statement. We must have confirmation that not only has the Government not made any decision to acquire and develop a nuclear capacity but also that it has not made a decision to ensure that the lead time--
—There is a complete and unequivocal commitment.

—If the Attorney-General now wishes to deny this statement by way of interjection, I would be pleased to accept that and sit down. I would be pleased to accept his denial that this Government has not given guidance for the purpose of review to ensure that the lead time for Australia could be matched to developments in other countries should the Government so decide.
—No specific endorsement of any specific thing in that paper.
—Will the Minister deny what I have just said that no guidance has been given for the purpose of review--
—Order! Senator Macklin, you must not incite opinions from the Attorney-General.

—Through the Chair, Mr Deputy President, I raise yet again the matter that I believe to be central to this issue: We have not had any denial from the Government that it has not done that. I waited for it and did not receive it. That is the crux of the concern being felt in the community today. I would be happy if the Government would now categorically deny it. However, the Government has refused to do so in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak, but if some well known anti-nuclear, anti-uranium campaigner on the other side of the chamber such as Senator McIntosh or Senator Coleman would like to get up and defend the Government I would certainly yield. I have not noticed any great enthusiasm for that course of action. I do not want to play politics; I think that is a terrible thing to do. I thought that, this morning, I would give a little bit of fatherly advice to my friend, if not colleague, Senator Grimes: If the Government ever gets in the clag, for goodness sake, put up a competent Minister to haul it out. Next time somebody like Senator Button or Senator Grimes himself should handle something like this because it is a bit unfair, not so much to Senator Evans, but to the Senate to have him handle these sorts of matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement that he put down on behalf of the Government-I suppose it could be called a confessional avoidance-at the very least is a very sloppy pleading. It is so sloppy that it certainly does not narrow the issues to what is before this high court of Parliament. I originally thought that this was typical of that sort of besotted exotic, erotic, tendentious trivia at which the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) is so magnificent. It is part and parcel of the way he writes. The article almost sounds like he thinks; say one thing one minute, and another thing the next. It is like him saying: 'If you don't like paragraph 1, 2, 3 and 4, then I will get paragraph 5, 6 and 7 for you'.

I understand that this statement is not a result of his drafting, that it has come from somewhere else. Is that right, Senator? Are you the author? If it has come from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), it is a magnificent example of what Max Harris said in last week's Weekend Australian was Bob's baffle gab as saying something in the first two paragraphs and deny them in the third and fourth paragraphs. The Minister's statement does not say anything. The Government is both for this and for that and against nothing. Actually, it is a disgraceful statement because, whether Senator Evans likes it or not, the Government cannot say what it does in paragraph 2 of that document and then go on and, in all honesty, say what it says in paragraphs 3 and 4.

What is interesting about the article in the National Times is something quite simple. None of us imagine that Brian Toohey would publish something which he knows is false. There is no way he would do that. He is a very experienced journalist. He may not be the most loved journalist by some members of the Parliament. Perhaps I should send him a cheerio and say: 'You are not the most loved, Brian, but you are generally respected as being pretty competent'. There is no way that Brian Toohey is going to publish something that he knows is false . He is not that stupid.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has done it before.

—Senator Evans said he has done it before. We will pass that message on to Brian Toohey; he has done it before according to Senator Evans. I do not think he could invent all this. Does it sound like some journalist's invention? Senator Chipp, who had a long career as a Minister, knows that it has all the hallmarks of something that has popped out of the bureaucracy. It has the style and the language. Brian Toohey would be the greatest plagiarist who ever existed if he could invent that sort of stuff! This is not an invented document. It has to have a lot of authenticity about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Before one asks why it was leaked one should ask oneself the question: Who leaked it? I put to the Senate that there are only three categories of people who have the capacity to get their hands on it and who, therefore, could leak it . One would be a Minister, one would be a ministerial staffer and the third would be a member of the Public Service because I understand that this document was not put in the Press boxes prior to it going to Cabinet. It would have been very tightly held. Those honourable senators who have been members of the Cabinet or of the Cabinet Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee know how tightly held these things are.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have the highest security classification.

—That is right. I can only speak from my time in the Fraser Ministry, but the outer Ministry never saw these documents. In fact, the whole of the Cabinet never saw these documents. They went to the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of Cabinet and were so strictly held that even staff members were not allowed to read them. They were terribly strictly held. All right, different governments have different ways of handling security matters. Perhaps when the statement is made next Monday we will have some explanation of the internal mechanisms used in handling documents of this capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, only three groups of people, a minister, a staffer or a Public Servant would handle these sorts of documents. One can then ask the question: Why should a person out of one of those three categories leak it-let it fall off a truck? Why would a Liberal supporter, a right winger or a fascist as we on this side of the chamber are all termed, leak a document like that? That category of person, in the general jargon of the Left, would certainly want that sort of document adopted. They would not want it let out to embarrass the Government. They would be delighted that the Government had adopted such a document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't you?
—It does not fuss me at all. I am not a flat-earther or a Malthusian or a Luddite. These things do not fuss me.
—Go on.

—The honourable senator should not entice me. Who would have leaked it? It had to be someone from the Left. I do not know about the gradations of the Left-whether there are centre Lefts or socialist Lefts. Somebody said there are centre left half backs and centre half forwards. I do not know whether they play rugby or Australian rules in the Labor Party; it is all very mixed up. I think a lot of them are playing a cricket match and they are nearly all out at silly point. It had to be somebody on the Left of Labor politics who leaked the document. It had to be someone within the three categories who was absolutely enraged at the double standards of the Hawke Government in saying one thing in public and doing another thing in private. That is why it was leaked to Brian Toohey. They felt it was such an outrageous betrayal of everything that the Labor Party has stood for in public that they had to put this matter on the public record to expose the double standards of the Hawke Government. That is why it was done. Anybody who knows anything about politics or human nature knows that is why it was done and that, therefore it was an authentic document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General can go on with all his sloppy pleading and the Prime Minister can go on with all of his baffle gab but they will not get away from that very simple issue. It is all there. Whoever put the ministerial statement together will have to do a lot better. It has been said here until we are sick of it, and I will sicken honourable senators a little bit more, that the Government cannot go on as it does in paragraph 2 by saying it was simply endorsed by way of guidance. For goodness sake, the people in the bureaucracy are not stupid. We are talking about people in the bureaucracy who are at the level to prepare this type of document. As Senator Macklin said, they are people on salaries of $50,000 a year plus. Unless it was quite a peculiar issue, public servants will not put something up which they know the Government will not accept under any circumstances. They know what the Government's policy is. They tend to put in things which they know the Government will accept. That is part of their duty. It is also part of the duty of the Public Service to put both views. One of the Australian Democrats-I think it was Senator Mason-said that it was not a paper of options, which is a normal Public Service document. In an initial stance one has options. I would have thought that there would be an options paper at the back of this document. These fellows were sent off after being told: 'No, we do not want those options; we want these options. Go and work us up another paper on those options'. That is the way governments of our persuasion tend to work. It may be that those on the right of you, Mr Deputy President, who are so besotted with exotica and trivia and all those other things that Senator Evans comes at, run a different type of government. So they came up with this paper.

The other thing I want to know is whether this paper was accepted on the day after the news that Australia II had won the America's Cup. Was the Cabinet meeting held on that day? It would be very interesting if it was. What ought to be recycled now is the marvellous television stuff of the Prime Minister at the Royal Perth Yacht Club, full of hype. Remember? Champagne was flowing everywhere . That is a great way to go to a Cabinet meeting to consider a document about nuclear weapons. Was the whole Cabinet hyped up? I appeal to Dr Grimes: Is that the sort of mental state members of Cabinet ought to be in when they consider a paper of this ilk? I suggest to the Australian Democrats, who are somewhat puzzled about why the paper got through, that perhaps that is how it got through . They were all hyped up. I invite honourable senators to look at the television program again. If members of Cabinet are in that sort of psychological state they are likely to do anything. Are they likely to know the difference between policy and platforms and expediency and ideology and so on?

TALK.START.PARA: —Guidelines.

—And guidelines. Perhaps the Cabinet is in that sort of hype every week. If it is it starts to explain some of the interesting decisions we are getting. We now have a socialist government which is beloved of business. It is one of those interesting chameleon operations one can come to. I see the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Grimes, looking at his watch, and I take the hint. I have no wish to bore him. If I continue much longer I will start to bore myself, and that would be tragic. I again plead with the Government, when it comes back with its statement on Monday, to get some competent people to put it together, to get a couple of competent pleaders, competent conveyancers, but stay away from those non-lawyers who masquerrade as lawyers in its Cabinet, like the doctor fellow in the other place who masquerades as a physician and surgeon. I ask the Government, when we come back on Monday, to explain all these matters to us in a simple, logical and concise way and in language which hangs together. If the Government needs paragraphs 5, 6 and 7, I ask it please to add them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the amendment to the motion moved by Senator Durack and support the previous speakers on this side of the chamber. This is the latest in an extraordinary series of blunders and public displays of incompetence that we have seen from this Government. Two major questions arise out of the matter. The first concerns modus operandi. How does this Government work? Have we ever seen a more incompetent bunch on the Treasury bench? The second concerns the contents of the document in question. We have been privileged to have the briefest statement that has ever been made in the history of this Parliament by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). As Senator Withers so cogently pointed out, that statement is just nonsense. The second paragraph is inconsistent and irreconcilable with the third and fourth paragraphs and with any of the numerous interjections the Attorney-General has made. The statement that has been put down is nonsense. We need a clear, concise and precise statement of what the Government is up to.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to some of the points that are brought up by this document, the most confidential document in the country. What sort of security does the Cabinet run when a document such as this can float around the streets? What discrepancies and divergences does it illustrate between what the Government says on the platform, what it says in the chamber, what it says on television, and what it is actually doing in private? What is the gross discrepancy between what the Government is saying in public and what it is saying to its own people, its own Party supporters, its sycophants in the branches through the length and breadth of this country, the people who write the Australian Labor Party doctrine? What does it say about breaches of Cabinet solidarity? What does it say about the lack of will to defend the essential interests of this country and the abject cowardice that some of the paragraphs contain? What about the disastrous consequences for Australian foreign relations? Those are just a few of the points that come immediately to mind when one sees this document in the National Times, a document whose authenticity has not been challenged by one word that has been said in this chamber this morning.

There is simply no more confidential document in the country than the document entitled 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy 1983'. Its publication destroys our security. It is a treasonable action. The document is the basis on which all our defensive posture is based, including our Defence Force structure and vital information for potential adversaries. It broadcasts our military appreciations of the region. It forecasts our decisions-what we will abjectly surrender and what we might defend. If this document is not safe, what document in the country is? How much damage has been done? How much vested interest is gained in the financial field if people are able to obtain Treasury documents? After all, if Mr Toohey, a journalist, can have direct access to this document, what will the professional agents of Soviet Russia and other countries around the world have? What access will the entrepreneurs from the business world and the drug runners of this country have to lesser documents?

I now turn to the discrepancies between what the Government is saying here and what it is saying in public. It is no overstatement to say that this destroys the very moral basis on which this Government holds office. It destroys the basis on which the Government ran for election. How can people such as the Government Whip, Senator McIntosh, or Senator Tate, who was present earlier, live with this. They are probably the only two genuinely sincere anti-nuclear people in this chamber, and even if they are wrong I do not criticise their position at all. How can they live with a government which acts like this in private? I do not see any difficulty for the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, or Senator Gareth Evans and bikies such as them. They are just thundering down the highway behind the pinball wizard on his Harley-Davidson, following a signpost that says: 'Power at any price; principles not mentioned'. They have no difficulty living with it, but I do feel for Senator McIntosh and Senator Tate on this issue.

We have raised the nuclear issue. I have a view that is different from that held by the Australian Democrats over nuclear armaments. I have never supported a nuclear posture for Australia, simply because it is too expensive and we have a far higher priority. When Australia has bought no new weapons for the Australian infantry for the last 20 years and when some soldiers are without boots, it is nonsense to suggest that Australia should be involved in the purchase of nuclear weapons. But I pose the question to this chamber: What would be the public debate in Australia if one of our near neighbours had a nuclear capacity? The debate in Australia would change dramatically from the hypothetical level on which it runs at the moment to one of a more realistic assessment of our defence needs. I do not know what would come out at the end.

I see nothing wrong with the Government exploring a nuclear option. I think it is common sense and is a responsible action. But why does the Government not tell us this? Why does the Government not take the Churchillian doctrine, by which most of us on this side live, of trusting the people? After all, it has a leader who stands up to the rostrum every day and says 'Trust me', and then doublecrosses the public. Why do we not just apply that doctrine literally and tell the people the truth of the matter? After all, the public are adult enough to know what is going on.

We come then to the business of breaches of Cabinet solidarity. We are all used to the factions in the Labor Party. As one Labor politician said to me: 'You never join the ALP, you join the faction first; the joining of the ALP is secondary to that'. We have seen the policy changes that have come from the various factions, and the inconsistencies; the way Mr Howe, on the extreme Left wing, administering defence support, speaks up in public and challenges statements that Cabinet has made. That is an intolerable situation. In US jargon , this ALP Federal Government is simply a floating crap game. It is a moving scene the whole time. No one knows what is going on in regard to policy.

I would like to home in now on Senator Ryan who, of course, once more is not here. Senator Ryan is a member of Cabinet who has run very strongly on a public posture about all the bleeding heart pacifist issues, all the world peace movement things, and all the pro-communist front organisations she can shelter behind, trying to get votes. How can she be party to a document that looks at a nuclear capability for Australia? How are we to judge Senator Ryan? Is she dishonest, is she irresponsible, or is she just plain silly?

Then I come to the business about the surrendering of the Cocos Islands, about which I spoke last night, and the craven cowardice that is displayed in this document about lack of will. I do not think any government in history in advance , even with the lack of any hypothetical threat, has ever offered to give up territory the way this Labor Government has. What does all the gung ho jingoism of the Prime Minsiter (Mr Hawke), with his rabid nationalism, stand for if the national interests of the country are not defended? Fancy giving up on the Cocos Islands, the key to the whole of the Indian Ocean. We have a record deficit in this country. The Cocos Islands are easy to defend and relatively cheap to defend. They would be very hard to take back if someone took them.

It is a simple matter of priorities for this Government. Rather than spending money on social engineering and trying to mess up society, as it is keen to do, it would be better off putting some military hardware into the Cocos Islands, and then that dreadful option of cowardice which it wants to display would not be necessary. I do not have time to go into the effect on the alliances, on ANZUS and the Association of South East Asian Nations relationships and the dreadful business of naming Indonesia and making a public display of it, as this document does. What does that do? Does that reflect the anti-Timor prejudice within the Labor Party and the lack of realisation of what is going on in the real world? I dealt with that briefly last night and will not repeat what I said as time is getting short. This document proves the lack of responsibility and lack of competence of the Government. I do not think any condemnation is strong enough for this chamber to move against the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If one good thing has come out of this debate-if that is what it can be called-it has been the exhumation of Senator Reg Withers. It was terrific to hear him speak again. I had forgotten what his voice was like. I shall take on board the points he made and see if we cannot improve things for him. He talked about hype and people performing in a situation of hype. I suppose it would be appropriate that he should be followed in the debate by Senator MacGibbon, the self-appointed expert on defence and foreign affairs in this Parliament, who gave us his usual performance and his extremist views full of all the hype and rhetoric that anyone would want to hear.

SPEECH.PARA: This document, or alleged document, was published in the National Times. I received my copy this morning but, clearly, Senator Chipp received his copy fairly late. All that Senator Chipp and the Opposition wanted to do was to move a motion to suspend Standing Orders. The time scale and the urgency were such that the motion to suspend Standing Orders could not be even properly typed and was hurriedly completed in someone's handwriting.

TALK.START.PARA: —So was the Government's statement. Senator Evans's statement was in handwriting.

—I am making the point that you and your colleagues are asking for an immediate, long and detailed account not only of the document that was published in the paper but the security of government documents. I put it to you that you have had your fun.
—We have acknowledged that you cannot produce this immediately.

—You have made your point. Your colleague Senator Mason, no matter what Senator Macklin says, announced that this document represented the Government's view-that the Government wanted to produce nuclear weapons and all the rest-despite the clear and concise statement made by Senator Gareth Evans on that matter on behalf of the Government. Senator Sir John Carrick, in his usual manner, condemned everyone, right, left and centre. He read part only of paragraph 2. He ignored the second sentence as it did not suit him. I will not say anything more about Senator Sir John Carrick as my views on him are known in this place. My views on anyone who gets up here and talks about corruption and lack of probity are well known.
—Why do you not play the ball?

—I played the ball. I sat here today and listened to Senator Sir John Carrick make a speech in which he dragged up everything that he believed had happened in the past year. He spoke about corruption not only in this Parliament but in New South Wales. I remind honourable senators, as I will always remind them, that he was a close confidant of one of the most corrupt Premiers that this country has ever had. For a long time he was secretary of a branch of a party which was responsible for the introduction of corruption in New South Wales. He has not denied that, and I doubt whether he will ever deny it. It is ill fitting for someone like that to get up and lecture this Parliament in the way he does.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have said we will do. Senator Gareth Evans has made a ministerial statement. Certainly it had to be put together in a hurry but it is a clear statement, I believe, and it gives the basis of the document. It confirms in a clear and concise way our attitude to nuclear weapons and the Nuclear Non- Proliferation Treaty. The Attorney-General has said that he and the Government will consider the second part of Senator Chipp's motion relating to the steps taken by the Government to keep the document secure-I agree that that must be of concern to all of us-and will do that as soon as possible. I think that the amendment is unnecessary. I do not know how 'a matter of urgency' is defined in that context. One could say that one wanted it this afternoon or next Monday. We accept that the numbers in this place are such that the amendment will be carried. Of course this is a serious matter, and the Government does treat it seriously and will continue to treat it seriously. We regard the matter of nuclear non-proliferation as serious. We will consider that in a serious way, as we have always done. That is why we made the clear and unequivocal statement today. I wish that everyone in the chamber treated it seriously.

I accept Senator Withers's speech, made in the spirit that it was, but I do not accept speeches like that of Senator MacGibbon, who poured out a litany of abuse of the Government on the basis of a document that apparently he believes had been leaked to the National Times. I do not accept that that is a reasonable way to debate a serious matter like this. We heard the speech of Senator Sir John Carrick, who dragged up everything that has happened in this Parliament, New South Wales and everywhere else in the past 12 months. I do not accept that Senator Macklin's and Senator Mason's interpretation of that document as meaning that we are about to produce nuclear weapons or are interested in doing so, in the face of the clear and concise statement made by Senator Gareth Evans, is a sensible and rational way to debate this issue at this time.

We have had almost three hours of debate on this and I dare say we will have more in view of the motion which has been moved and the amendment to that motion which has been moved by Senator Durack. I hope that over the weekend people will consider the seriousness of the situation. They should consider whether the Government is in fact taking a serious attitude on this in the clear statement it has made.

We will take on board the second part of the motion by Senator Chipp and see in what way the security and methods of security of Government documents can be reasonably debated in this place, if they can be. One would not want to expose to the light of day all the methods of securing documents. I do not think that is wise and I do not think anyone, on reflection, would believe that that was wise. We oppose the amendment. We agreed to the motion to enable this debate to take place. We accept that the numbers are such that the amendment will get through and we will take it from there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been considerable debate on the motion which I originally moved for the Senate to take note of the statement and on Senator Durack's amendment, which seeks to put into the motion the request which I made in my speech; that is, that we should have the delivery of a further statement from the Government and that the Government should also attend to the issue of the security which attached to this very important document. There is no need for us to take very much notice of the criticisms of Senator Grimes about the fact that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have paid attention to this matter. This morning the Minister who has been most publicly involved, the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes), said on the AM program of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the problem with that type of alleged security leak is that it does damage to our security operations and it can cause serious damage to relations with our neighbours.

They are the words of the Minister for Defence. We are dealing with a matter which in his view can cause serious damage to relations with our neighbours and can do damage to our security operations. The debate was not assisted by the attempts made by Senator Grimes to smear Senator Sir John Carrick. They were not so much accusations as simply a running together of statements which could to a weak-minded person suggest accusations. I make it quite clear that Senator Sir John Carrick was, to the knowledge of us all, the General Secretary of the Liberal Party of Australia in New South Wales for many years. During that period he was undoubtedly a respected and close adviser to both Premiers and Prime Ministers. I simply say that I note that in the very careful choosing of words by Senator Grimes there was no hint of any allegation of corruption on the part of my colleague Senator Sir John Carrick; rather, there was mention of the possibility of corruption among others and, I would say, a classic attempt to promote guilt by association. I express nothing but contempt for that. It added nothing to the debate.

When the Government responds, as I am sure it will, to the motion requesting a further statement, I ask the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to address the doubts which arise as a result of the form of the written statement which he originally provided and from which he read. There are some significant amendments to the typed document from which he read and subsequent copies which have been circulated do not show those differences. It is important to note that the original typed statement at paragraph 2 read as follows:

To the extent that a document of that title was considered by Cabinet last year , it was endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies.

That paragraph has been amended in handwriting, which does not appear to be the handwriting of the Attorney, to add the word 'simply' before the word 'endorsed' so that the expression of endorsement is in a sense written down. A further sentence has been added as follows:
It is not a policy document but to the extent that any policy prescriptions were contained in it these were not specifically endorsed.
It appears to me that that is simply an attempt to write down and obscure the fact that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Bob's bafflegab.
—I welcome the interjection from my colleague Senator Withers. It is typical of the sort of very fudged language which is a hallmark of this Government, and of the Prime Minister in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the basic admission of the Government is that this was a document prepared for the purpose of guiding those reviewing our defence planning and the development of our defence policies. Therefore, the significance of the document should not be ignored. This is an extremely serious matter. It is a matter in which the Government has a great deal to answer for. We look forward to a very early response from the Government to the request which I am sure the Senate will make on the passage of the motion.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Durack's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Senate will know that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) in speaking about the defence papers, set out to heap personal invective upon me and to reflect upon my integrity. That is no new tactic. As a Minister of the previous Government and Leader of the Government in the Senate for some seven years I had to face up to the fact that Senator Grimes sat in here in an abusive fashion every day and, trying not to be heard by the Chair so that he would not be picked up, cast the same kind of abuse.
