SPEECH.PARA: Today the Minister said two main things. He said-and he did so from the coward' s castle of this Parliament-that the late Sir Robert Askin was the most corrupt Premier in Australia. Let the world judge the character and integrity and the corruption or otherwise of Senator Grimes on the fact that he says that of a dead man and of a family that has no way of responding. Let the Minister measure that against his own Party's performance in its branches in New South Wales and the New South Wales Parliament. I say simply to him, non-medically: Physician cure thyself of this. Sir Robert Askin was the Premier of New South Wales for 10 or 11 years and, by popular consent, gave good government to that State. Nobody has been able to lay a specific charge and make that charge stick. I know of no kind of corrupt behaviour by Sir Robert Askin. If there were such, it should be exposed. I was never associated with or had any knowledge of any such incident.

Senator Grimes went on to say that I was the General Secretary of a Liberal Party that was corrupt. I can only say that I know of no such incident and certainly I was not associated with corruption. Since this matter has been going on for eight years, let me be more specific. As to my personal integrity, I invite Senator Grimes to refer-preferably outside this Parliament but here if he wants the protection-to any such incident or give any facts at all about any part of my post-war journey in public life. Let him do it and I will willingly make available all evidence regarding my own personal effects and my own financial arrangements and that of my family during the whole of the journey. I make that perfectly clear without qualification. No one can do more than that.

If Senator Grimes wants to use this chamber in a larrikin way, as he does because he is the larrikin of this Parliament, let everyone judge him on his actions. I invite him to walk outside now and make any specific charges he likes to make about me. We should bear in mind that Senator Grimes said that during my time I have criticised the Australian Labor Party and alleged it has been guilty of misbehaviour. I have never at any time in this Parliament attacked the personal integrity of any member of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.
—Never. Let the Opposition Whip, who says I have, go to Hansard. I have attacked the Labor Party generally on its behaviour.
—What about what you said about Whitlam. You were talking about personalities then.

—Certainly I attacked the behaviour of the Whitlam Government as regards the Khemlani affair. Of course, it was an attack on integrity. Let me make it clear that the aim of all the interjections over the years has been to suggest by innuendo that somehow or other I have been engaged in some improper practices. I make the unqualified statement that that is emphatically false. I say that without any qualification at all. I make the offer that I will have examined any episode, any journey and any kind of incident in my life that he likes to put up. I will make available all my own documents. He can have, if he wants, continuous information from the Australian Taxation Office, banks or anywhere else.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than gaining a penny out of politics over the journey, I think those who know me know that I was the poorest paid official of a political party at that time. This was at my own choice because we were broke. Indeed, I gained nothing out of the journey directly or indirectly, nor did my family. That is a fair offer. I just hope that in future we will play the ball. I could have reminded Senator Grimes of the many incidents concerning his Party, such as the one that concerned the Marrickville branch. I have not done so. Rather, I hone in on the specifics. If Senator Grimes wants to make a personal attack, let him do so and let him be specific but, since we are supposed to be testing integrity, let us do that in public.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have waited some time for Senator Sir John Carrick to come in here and make the sort of statement he has just made. I find it a surprising statement in view of the fact that I have been in this House for almost 10 years and in that time I have heard Senator Sir John Carrick blackguard specifically Mr Whitlam, Mr Connor, Jim Cairns and I think Mr Clyde Cameron. I have heard him blackguard collectively every Labor senator in this place, accusing them of being part of a corrupt organisation, at times accusing them of being communist or friends of communists , and in fact at times accusing them of almost treasonable behaviour. I have complained about that repeatedly in this place and on many occasions I have said to Senator Sir John Carrick: 'You stop that behaviour, you stop abusing the Standing Orders in this place in the way you do and I and others will stop replying in kind'. It may not be a very edifying spectacle to see Senator Sir John Carrick on one side and me on the other carrying on the way we do. But it is quite unreasonable to expect people on the Labor benches to sit and listen day after day to the abuse we used to get from the then Leader of the Government and not reply.
—You are intimidating. You are attempting intimidation by the way you carry on.

—I have said to Senator Sir John Carrick on many occasions: 'If you don't like the heat, get out of the kitchen. If you don't want to cop it back, don't do it in the first place'. I have always made that offer.
—All of you do it in a snide way under the table. You never get up and state it openly.

—If ever there were an example of Satan condemning sin, it is you , Senator Lewis, who uses the same tactics as Senator Sir John Carrick. I am quite happy never to mention the gentleman's name again ever. I certainly will if we have to put up with the sanctimonious nonsense we get about Whitlam, Cairns and everybody else.
—Have the courage to go outside and do it.

—The difficulty is, and will continue to be, that if Senator Sir John Carrick wishes to get up and blackguard me and my colleagues in the way he has done in the past we will reply in kind. The answer is simple: If you do not like it, do not do it.

—by leave-It should be noted that the point raised by Senator Sir John Carrick has simply not been met. There is plenty of hard political debate in this place-and that should be the case. That debate goes to the integrity of the actions of government, to the wisdom of such actions and whether governments are competent and capable. Extremely hard words will be said in the course of those debates. I listened most carefully to what was said by Senator Sir John Carrick. He referred to personal accusation or accusations which went to his personal integrity and honesty, which is a totally different kettle of fish. I simply wish to say that the points made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) totally ignored the challenge made by Senator Sir John Carrick. He made the position clear that he would meet any specific allegations and challenged Senator Grimes to say the sort of things he said sotto voce in this place outside the chamber or in a specific way. Senator Grimes referred to the often warm and, indeed, heated debate that takes place on matters of politics, policy and government in this place. I believe there is a clear distinction to be drawn that will not escape either senators or members of the public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since other persons are concerned about their sensibilities and their reputations being impugned by remarks made in this place, I wish to place on record my total rejection of the implication in the remarks of Senator MacGibbon concerning my involvement with and advocacy of the peace movement. I was in my office engaged on other business when I heard Senator MacGibbon's remark over the loud speaker. I have not had the opportunity to read those words , but it was clear to me that any person listening to him would have got the impression that my advocacy of peace and disarmament meant that I was also in some way an advocate of the communist cause. I am not prepared to have that said here or in any other place. I am not prepared to have the sincere and effective efforts of our Government to work nationally and internationally for the goal of world peace derided as some kind of pro-communist propaganda. I am not prepared to have all the genuine Australian men and women, who in increasing numbers are working hard in their various organisations for the objective of world peace, derided as either dupes of the communist cause or in some way or other supporters of the communist cause. I am certainly not prepared to have those imputations made about me here or anywhere else.

SPEECH.PARA: In common with every other member of the Australian Labor Party, I am committed to working for peace. I am prepared to use my position as a Minister in the Cabinet to advance that cause in whatever way I can. Whenever I do so, I have the total support of the ALP and the Labor Government. I am unprepared to accept that the advocacy of world peace brings me into any kind of relationship with the Communist Party or any communist organisation. It is particularly appalling that Senator MacGibbon chose to make his remarks today, some 12 hours or so after we had in this place yesterday an edifying debate which was participated in by members of all parties on the subject of world peace and disarmament.

Senator Sir John Carrick spoke most impressively in that debate on the desirability of everybody working towards that objective, as indeed did other senators on both sides of the House. It is a most counter-productive approach to take to such a serious topic, for whatever political benefit Senator MacGibbon imagines he can obtain. I imagine he has some far right constituency he is trying to impress with his performance. It is counter-productive to attempt to debate the serious discussions we have been having in this House about disarmament and to debate my commitment or that of anybody in the present Government, or indeed the commitment of any Australian citizen towards the most important objective of all, that of world peace and disarmament.
Sitting suspended from 12.48 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General in his dual capacity of Minister representing the Minister for Defence and Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the Cabinet consider the document entitled 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy 1983' at its meeting in Perth on 19 September last year? If so, to what degree did the Government endorse the document? How is it possible to endorse even in the most general way a paper which apparently canvasses a possibility said to be totally against Government policy, that is, the development of a nuclear weapons capacity for Australia?
—As Senator Sir John Carrick well knows, I made a statement on this subject this morning, and I do not propose to add to it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and refers to workers compensation and occupational health and safety. Is the Minister aware that many workers are afraid to inform employers of work injuries or to take off necessary recuperation time for fear of not retaining their jobs? Can the Minister say whether these factors are being covered by the Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission's investigations? Does the Minister see the issue of workers compensation as a major issue to resolve before occupational health and safety policies can be truly workable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob was kind enough to give me some notice of this question in view of the fact that it goes to details of the administration of the portfolio of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis , whom I represent in the Senate. The Minister is aware, and I am aware from my own experience, that in many parts of industry there is an under-reporting of work injuries and work hazards, particularly in times of severe unemployment such as we have experienced in the last few years. The Health and Safety Commission has been conducting public discussions in all States and the Territories and has received over 100 submissions which have highlighted a broad range of problems in the reporting of work injuries. It is too early yet to reach any conclusions about how those problems might be dealt with, but the primary responsibility for both workers compensation and occupational health and safety rests with the State and Territory governments. Some form of investigation in both these areas is currently being undertaken by these governments.

ANSWER.PARA: The question is not so much one of whether workers compensation is an issue to resolve before occupational health and safety policies can be truly workable, but rather a question of occupational health and safety policies bringing about an effective reduction in occupational injury and ill health and, therefore, a corresponding reduction in workers compensation claims. The emphasis in occupational health and safety policies is firstly on prevention. Governments recognise the absolute impossibility of completely eliminating all occupational injury and ill health, so a second major emphasis has to be on rehabilitation. The Government's policies recognise that rehabilitation must encompass job retraining as well as financial support or compensation during the period in which a worker is unable to engage in employment as a result of occupational injury or ill health.

I add to that answer that the greatly escalating costs of workers compensation premiums are a very big and significant add-on cost to the general costs of Australian industry. For that reason, the Government places a great deal of emphasis on reducing the number of injuries which might subsequently become compensable under workers compensation legislation. The issue of workers compensation costs to industry is a very big one which the Government has to address in a variety of ways. The initiative in respect of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is an important way of addressing that very serious problem.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the concept of ministerial responsibility as outlined by Mr Malcolm Fraser:

QUESTION.PARA: It is certainly true that Ministers cannot be aware of everything that occurs in their departments. They ought to be aware of all the major matters and therefore can be clearly and directly responsible for them but if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, that Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his Department and offer to resign.

I remind the Attorney that he first embraced this approach in September 1982 and repeated his support for it on 2 December in the debate over the responsibilities of the Foreign Minister and the Minister for Defence regarding the Australian Secret Intelligence Service incident at the Sheraton Hotel. I ask the Attorney: Does he believe that the Minister for Defence should offer to resign over the leaking of the Government's 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy 1983'?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen in the past some merit in the Fraser approach to ministerial responsibility as expressed in that statement. I have expressed, however, my regret in the past, and I do so again today, that that statement was clearly never taken very seriously by Mr Fraser himself or by Ministers in his Government during their tenure in office. As a result, through disuse, it must be regarded as having lapsed into abeyance. In any event, even were the principle to have any continuing force or effect, I am clearly of the view that it has no application whatsoever in the present circumstances.

—Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs comment on a recent Press statement by Senator Macklin on the repatriation legislation review in which he claimed, amongst other things, that the onus of proof for determination of disability pension claims would be reversed and that dependants' pensions would be abolished? Are these claims correct? What is the objective of the review and when will the new legislation take effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The review of repatriation legislation has been proceeding during 1983 and has as its objective the simplifying, rationalising and consolidating of the many Acts of Parliament that deal with repatriation and associated benefits for veterans who served in wars and in peacekeeping exercises. As well, there has been an administrative review council dealing with the legislation that handles the processes by which entitlements and benefits are made available to veterans. The consequences of those two studies that have been carried out over the past year or so have been designed not to take away benefits from any of the veterans concerned, not to either reduce or extend them , but rather to simplify the processes by which veterans can apply for such benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, as with any rationalisation exercise, the review has necessarily entailed some minor policy changes, but no beneficiary will be affected as a result of the proposed legislation, which will ultimately be available for debate in the Parliament. I advise Senator Colston that preliminary discussions have been held with representatives of the veteran community-we as a government believe in consultation-regarding the content of the new legislation. Many ideas have been floated with the advisory committee that was established. On a confidential basis, copies of a draft Bill have been made available to the organisation. The advisory committee has been invited to respond, again on the basis of confidentiality. As a result of that interchange of ideas, changes have been made to the original proposals from the committee that has been looking at both the process of determining pensions as well as the review of the Repatriation Act. In the due process of time I will be making appropriate recommendations to Cabinet. I think it would be inappropriate for me at this stage to comment any more on that debate within Cabinet.

I stress particularly to Senator Macklin that no veteran who is currently receiving benefits will be adversely affected by the review. I was therefore very disturbed to read the statements made by the spokesman for the Australian Democrats on this matter which created some confusion and some concern. They were completely and thoroughly unjustified. I had to repudiate the statements made by Senator Macklin. As he was quoting from documents which were given to the members of the advisory committee on a confidential basis, it seems to me that no good purpose would be served by having such a public debate about them at this stage. The Parliament will have the ultimate opportunity to look at the legislation. If it wants to amend it, the due processes will be available to those who do not believe that the Government's response to the legislation is adequate or otherwise. However, I make it very clear that the statements made by Senator Macklin were incorrect and created a great deal of mischief and concern. I regret that that has happened because the committee does not need to be put in a position where it believes benefits are being taken away from veterans when that is not the objective of the legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . How many nuclear reactors or nuclear technology facilities for research, civil or military purposes are operating in Australia? How many such facilities are in place but not operating? What are the specific functions of each of these facilities? Do any of these facilities produce fissile material that could be used or made suitable for use in nuclear weapons? If no such facilities exist in Australia does the Government have any plans or decisions to develop or establish facilities that could produce fissile material potentially suitable for nuclear weapons? Does the Government accept, endorse and expect to follow the Australian Labor Party platform on nuclear power? That platform states:

QUESTION.PARA: Prohibit the establishment in Australia of nuclear power plants and all other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure how wide the extension of nuclear technology facilities may be. For example, work on uranium testing was being conducted at the Amdel laboratory in Adelaide. I think it is a matter of arbitrary decision whether that would be classified as a nuclear technology facility. There are two nuclear reactors at Lucas Heights-the HIFAR reactor and a very much smaller one. Before a definitive answer could be given I think the terms of the first three questions need to be tightened up. I was asked: 'How many nuclear technology facilities for research, civil or military purposes, are operating in Australia' , and 'Do any of these facilities produce fissile material.' My understanding-I will check this with people whose technological expertise is greater than mine- is that it is probably technically feasible, as fissile materials are in the cores that are coming out of the Lucas Heights reactor, but extremely difficult, to produce nuclear weapons from that. There are probably insufficient quantities in total to produce them anyway, but if they are accumulated for long enough I think it would be technically feasible but highly unlikely.

ANSWER.PARA: The second last part of the question was: 'If no such facilities exist in Australia does the Government have any plans or decisions to develop or establish facilities', et cetera. The answer to that is unequivocally no. Senator Mason's final query contained a quotation from the Labor Party platform. I think I dealt with that question yesterday. There is general agreement that the present Labor Party platform is internally, if not inconsistent, certainly ambiguous and is capable of being interpreted in a variety of ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister invited me, I think properly, to tighten up the second part of my question, and I shall do so. Specifically, what has happened to the experiments on centrifuge enrichments which were being carried out at Lucas Heights?

—The centrifuge enrichment program, which was under way at the time this Government came to power, has continued. There was a proposal to expand that centrifuge program and I think to increase by more than 100 per cent the funds which were devoted to it. That expansion program was cancelled by the Government but the existing level of activity was maintained and will continue, I think, for about another 12 months until that program is completed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. What concessions has the Government offered in order to resolve the dispute with doctors over Medicare contracts for doctors working in public hospitals? Can he also say what has been the response of the Australian Medical Association to the Government's concessions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am sure Senator Bolkus and others realise, and as has been recognised in the Press, there have been concessions from the word 'go' by the Minister for Health and this Government in endeavouring to settle the dispute. The Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals was established partly for this purpose. Dr Blewett has accepted the sensible suggestion of the Australian Democrats and Senator Haines to allow pro tem the Senate to oversee the contracts or the regulations brought forward in the application of section 17 of the Health Insurance Act.

ANSWER.PARA: All the way along, the Minister for Health has endeavoured to come to a reasonable agreement with the doctors in these circumstances. The sticking point clearly is the reasonable request of the Government that doctors should charge the schedule fee when using publicly funded facilities in public hospitals. Some sections of the medical community talk about high principle and about the Minister having untrammelled powers over them through his capacity to set out the guidelines under which those contracts shall be drawn up. That has been demonstrated to be wrong. The fact that they did not back down when the Minister made his concessions demonstrated that the real sticking point is how much money they can get when they are using those public facilities to treat patients in public hospitals. I think it is disappointing that the medical profession, or some sections of it, continue to take that attitude. I am not the only one who thinks that. In fact the Adelaide News, which is certainly not a radical socialist paper under any circumstances, stated in an editorial on 29 March:
. . . on any reasonable assessment of the dispute, it is obvious that the Federal Government has bent over backwards to accommodate the doctors.
For doctors then to take to the streets of Adelaide and other cities and to threaten a national strike is irresponsible and wrong.
Hippocrates must be spinning in his grave.

I think that just about sums up the situation. I hope that those responsible members of the medical profession who are disturbed at the escalation of the present dispute will prevail over their more radical colleagues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to an answer he gave to Senator Chaney on Tuesday of this week about the decision to defer the introduction of the Bill of Rights legislation promised by the Prime Minister in his policy speech last year, the early introduction of which has been foreshadowed on a number of occasions by the Attorney-General himself, variously at the end of last session, then at the beginning of this session and now, of course, down on the back burner apparently until after the next election. I draw the Attorney's attention particularly to his answer to Senator Chaney, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Bill of Rights . . . is very close to fruition, although I was hoping for more substantial consultations with . . . other relevant interested groups before actual introduction.

I ask the Attorney: Is this work continuing and, if so, as soon as the Bill is completed will he make it available as an exposure draft just as he has done with other proposed legislation so that the widest community reaction and discussion can take place? If not, how can he justify Australians being kept in the dark as to this Government's intentions when they go to the polls at the early election promised by the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that might reasonably be regarded as a tendentious question. It would not appear to be motivated by any particular genuine search for truth; it would appear to show an intentional bias and it is clearly calculated to promote a particular viewpoint or cause. I make clear that proper usage demands, as the Concise Oxford Dictionary points out, that the word be used in a derogatory sense, and I do so now. It would appear that the National Times is as illiterate as it is amoral.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me press on to the circumstances of this question. It is true, as I said the other day, that the Bill of Rights is very close to fruition in terms of its drafting, although it is certainly proposed that there be extensive consultations on a confidential basis with the States, the Law Council of Australia and certain other interested groups which may contribute something constructive to the final drafting of that legislation. As I also said the other day, I do not believe and the Government does not believe that it is appropriate for legislation to be introduced in isolation from the other parts of the total human rights package that we are preparing; namely, that package dealing in particular with the structuring of the Human Rights Commission and also amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act. On the current timetable, it looks as though those aspects of the legislation are unlikely to be ready until some considerable number of months hence. I will give consideration to the matter raised by Senator Durack, whether in a genuine search for truth or not, as to whether or not it is appropriate at an early stage to make available an exposure draft of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. When did the Government decide that the Bill was to be in a package with other human rights legislation? How does the Attorney now relate that statement about a package to the very firm promises he made last year about an early introduction of the Bill of Rights?
—The Government decided to have a package in December last year and I announced it at the time.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Does the Government intend to take action to restore the right of the Australian National University Students Association to allocate its own funds, which affect its right of affiliation-a right which was removed by the previous Government?

—Yes, the Government does intend to restore to student organisations in the Australian Capital Territory the rights that they had prior to the changes made by the Fraser Government, including the right to determine like any other group in our society the way its funds will be spent. I am hoping that the Senate will have that legislation before it shortly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SEX DISCRIMINATION ACT: ADVERTISING OF PROVISIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Is the Human Rights Commission planning to spend more than $1m advertising the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act? How does the Attorney-General justify such a massive campaign at a time when senior Ministers are warning of the need for restraint in Government spending to make room for tax cuts in the coming Budget?

—I hope that the Human Rights Commission is planning to spend about $1m on promoting the Sex Discrimination Act, although I am not in a position to confirm the accuracy of that figure. The justification for such expense at this time is that the Sex Discrimination Act is a fundamental piece of reforming legislation seen, properly, as being of supreme significance by half the Australian community-the women of Australia who for so long have been discriminated against by prejudiced males, some of whom are well represented in this chamber and are wholly insensitive to the aspirations of the women of this country in areas such as employment and occupation, housing, access to goods and services and all the other matters with which the Sex Discrimination Act deals. It is in that context that it is entirely appropriate, and the Government will go on believing it is entirely appropriate, to spend appropriate amounts of money on the advertising of the procedures and rights created under this Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Has the Minister seen the article in the Age of 7 March 1984 headed ' Too few students finish high school . . .' in which Professor Caro, Vice- Chancellor of Melbourne University, highlights the numbers of students not completing secondary education and the few going into tertiary institutions. Professor Caro said:

QUESTION.PARA: The present Government has stated its intention to increase participation in education, but has not yet done anything very dramatic about it.

Can the Minister put on record once again the reasons for the problems facing secondary and tertiary institutions, particularly the Fraser Government's contribution, or lack of it, to education and what this Government has done and is doing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Professor Caro's view about the failure of our institutions to attract an adequate number of young people into higher education and training. I am pleased that people with positions of high credibility in the education debate, such as Professor Caro, are speaking out on this matter. I think it does help the community to understand the defective situation we inherited from the Fraser Administration. I am sure Professor Caro, like any responsible administrator in higher education, will agree that the problems we are now tackling are problems that we inherited from the previous Administration , which presided over seven years of funding cuts to higher education. Those funding cuts not only reduced the places available but also reduced the capacity of universities and colleges to develop appropriate courses, to maintain standards in some cases, to replace obsolete equipment and indeed to house the number of students seeking places. There was a dramatic, scandalous run-down in funds available for capital and equipment and also a very serious decline in the funds available for recurrent expenditure in higher education. Of course this run-down of higher education by the Fraser Administration is the main reason we are now seeing in more optimistic times an excess of demand for higher education places.

ANSWER.PARA: However I cannot agree with the suggestion, if Professor Caro made it, that our Government is not acting to redress this situation. In our first Budget we provided $10m for an extra 3,000 places over and above what had been provided for the triennium by the previous Government. Those 3,000 places have been taken up very readily and I am particularly pleased to note that they have been taken up in areas where, in the past, access to higher education has been very difficult. They have been taken up by our newer universities and by our colleges of advanced education in outer metropolitan and regional areas. Access to higher education is not simply a matter of a place being available somewhere; it is a matter of places being available where people live or where they can easily travel to. This has happened under our participation program. Similarly our Cabinet, realising the urgency of the demand for places in higher education, by bringing forward about $14m worth of capital projects has facilitated the work of those institutions taking in extra students. I hope and expect that we will make a more significant contribution to providing more places and to providing for growth over the next triennium in our Budget deliberations. Obviously I cannot make any specific predictions now. It is important that the community realises that we have far too low a participation rate in higher education. It is important that university and college administrators realise this and be prepared publicly to debate the importance of the matter. I believe governments can act effectively only when there is community understanding and support for what we want to do. We want to regenerate higher education; we want to upgrade it; we want to improve the standards; we certainly want to upgrade research into it; and we want to increase access to it. In order to do all of those things we do need informed public debate so I welcome, in general, the contribution of distinguished administrators such as Professor Caro.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Attorney-General have any discussions with a member of the High Court of Australia bench about the Combe-Ivanov affair in the period leading up to the announcement of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia' s Security and Intelligence Agencies? If so, did he seek any advice from the judge about national security matters?
—I have no recollection whatsoever of having ever had any such discussions.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to a report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald in which the Opposition's spokesman on health, Mr Carlton, warned that the failure on the part of the Government to amend section 17 of the Health Insurance Act could see the current dispute with the doctors ending up in the High Court of Australia on the grounds that it contravenes section 51 of the Commonwealth Constitution? Can the Minister indicate what would be the likely cost to the public purse of such a move? What would be the likely success of such a move?

—The last part of the question involved my giving a legal opinion. If the real lawyers in this place are not allowed to give legal opinions, bush lawyers like me should not either although, if Senator Withers is any guide, my opinions are likely to be as good as those of the rest of them. I saw the article in the Sydney Morning Herald in which Mr Carlton, apparently on behalf of the medical profession, threatened that the dispute over section 17 would end up in the High Court. I do not know on what basis he was speaking. One certainly has not heard that from the medical profession. The Minister for Health and the Government are determined to settle this dispute without any recourse to the High Court. We have set up the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. The Minister has made concessions to the medical profession on many occasions so that this dispute can be settled. I do not know what the costs of such a disputation in the High Court would be, but judging from the cost of the Greek conspiracy case and others and given the fees sought by our leading Queen's Counsel, all I can say is heaven knows; the sky is probably the limit. However, whatever the cost and whatever the delays, the only people who would really suffer in the end would be the patients and particularly those patients who have no choice but to go to public hospitals. I hope the matter does not go to the High Court. I hope it is settled before then.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Were the pre-Budget quota controls on the clearance of cigarettes imposed earlier than usual last year? Is the Minister aware that there was an abnormally high-in fact, extremely so-level of clearance of cigarettes immediately prior to that unusually early imposition of those pre-Budget quota controls in late June last year? Has the Minister been asked to consider holding an inquiry into the possible leakage of his decision to impose pre-Budget quota controls earlier than usual last year? If so, what was his response to the request? If not, will he now consider holding such an inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the pre-Budget quotas on tobacco products, potable spirits and beer were imposed earlier than usual last year. Senator Peter Rae can believe it or not-I am sure he will-but the purpose of that was to try to cut out the unnecessary speculation which normally occurs in the pre- Budget period. It was felt that if the quotas were applied earlier than usual the speculation process might be aborted. I am also aware that there was a very high clearance of tobacco products in the two days immediately prior to the announcement of the pre-Budget quotas. The total amount involved for the three tobacco companies was $4.3m above normal clearances. I should also point out that W. D. and H. O. Wills (Australia) Ltd alone, in the two or three days prior to the May 1983 economic statement being made, cleared approximately $6m worth of products in anticipation that the statement would contain quotas. In that sense it has to be set in some degree of context.

ANSWER.PARA: My recollection of whether I was asked to consider whether there should be an investigation into this matter-I would certainly like the opportunity to refresh my memory on this-is that I was asked whether there should be an investigation and, in the course of discussions, decided that there should not be. The reason for that was that there were a very large number of departmental officers involved in the need-to-know process in my Department as well as in other departments. In those circumstances it was considered highly unlikely that the source of any leak, if there was one, could be identified. I certainly remember having a discussion about the matter in the course of which I tried to ascertain how many other departments, apart from the Department of Industry and Commerce, were in the need-to-know situation. There were several. In those circumstances I felt that such an inquiry would probably be unsuccessful in producing any result .

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a supplementary question, Mr President. I was directing the question to the fact that there was an unusually early imposition. The May statement was anticipated. Therefore, the tobacco companies could anticipate a rise in the price of their products. That imposition of quota controls was applied at an unusually early date.
—Senator Rae, are you asking a question?

—Yes. The question I wish to ask is: Is it not a notorious fact that a person is under suspicion in relation to this matter? Would not an inquiry help in identifying whether that is correct or otherwise? Will the Minister in replying now or later, after he has refreshed his memory, keep those two matters in mind?

—I am aware that it was an unusually early imposition. I certainly was very conscious of that. As I said, it was done for a particular purpose. To my knowledge it is not a notorious fact that a particular person is under suspicion. Certainly at the time that I had some discussions about this question it was not suggested to me that any individual or identifiable group of individuals was under suspicion and notoriously so. In the light of the latter part of Senator Rae's question, I will certainly make further inquiries.

—Did the Minister for Education see an article by Helen Trinca in today's Australian entitled 'Top uni students ''mostly wealth'' '? How does Professor John Western's research on the relatively privileged backgrounds of the majority of university students, especially in medicine and law, measure up to the Government's own information? What measures will the Government take to ensure that students from less privileged backgrounds are not excluded from Australian universities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did read with great interest the newspaper report of Professor Western's research, because obviously it is of great concern to the Government that we introduce a measure of equity into the matter of access to higher education. I will seek to get a copy of Professor Western's survey so I can study it carefully. I am advised by the Tertiary Education Commission that the kinds of findings in Professor Western's research are reinforced by the information available to the Commission. The Commission advises me that if we were to divide university students in Australia into three groups we would find that of people in the high category, that is, the high socio-economic group, almost 20 per cent attend university compared with 9.1 per cent in the middle socio-economic group and 6.6 per cent in the low socio-economic category. The way to address that is not simply to request the universities to broaden access without making any changes. I think the way to address it is to look at the reasons why students from lower socio-economic backgrounds do not get to the point of academic performance where they can get into faculties such as medicine and law. If we are to do that we have to recognise that many of the schools serving the poorer communities have not had available to them adequate resources to prepare students adequately with that aptitude for universities.
—Do you think it all happens at schools?

—It is a complicated argument. I am not quite sure what the point of Senator Baume's interjection is. Quite clearly, some schools are better able to prepare talented students for entry into prestigious university faculties than other schools. It is certainly the case that students from poorer families, because of their family backgrounds, have further obstacles to achieve.
—Hooray! Ha, ha, ha!

—It is quite apparent that socio-economic standing and ability are not always positively correlated. There are many examples of that in this place. Our Government is seriously concerned, to put it simply, that students from a poorer background or students who attend schools in poorer areas have many obstacles in their way to enter faculties such as medicine and law. We realise that the solution to this is not simple. We realise that it involves improving the educational standards in the schools that these students attend. I accept, and I believe the Government accepts, that it will mean providing a higher level of income support for students from poorer families so they are able to complete their secondary schooling. It will probably mean a higher level of support for tertiary students because many students from poorer backgrounds have the qualifications to pursue a high level tertiary degree but cannot afford to do so .

ANSWER.PARA: It is a complex matter of disadvantage that we are addressing. We are addressing it both through our improvements in schools programs, our increases for student allowances and also in our discussions and debates with the university sector so that they can look at their selection criteria to ensure that they are not using irrelevant selection criteria but are using criteria that have to do with student ability and aptitude and not socio-economic status.

Can the Minister advise whether the administrative machinery to make these payments is complete? If so, how many claims for moneys have been received, how many claims have been paid and how many claims are outstanding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some years the Torres Strait Islanders and a number of Aborigines in the northern part of Australia have been pressing a claim upon the Commonwealth Government in respect of the underpayment of benefits as a result of their war service during World War II regarding both payment as servicemen and payments by the former Repatriation Department. A search of the records has established to my satisfaction that there had been underpayment in respect of both those who served in the war and those who were eligible for benefits from my Department. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to his statement in response to a question yesterday that he was personally satisfied that the nuclear waste disposal problem had been satisfactorily resolved. —Senator Grimes suggested that I should tell Senator Chaney that there is a secret method of disposal which I am not allowed to disclose. I will not do that because I do not need to resort to that sort of subterfuge or evasion. It may well be that the vitrification and synroc processes are satisfactory. If Senator Chaney wants to know the thing that impressed me most of all, it was the visit to the Swedish experimental installation at Stripa. The proposal-although not at Stripa-is that copper cannisters containing the unreprocessed rods, the cooled rods as they have come out of the reactor, are packed in bentonite clay very tightly and disposed of in granite. There are elements of judgment involved in this. They are subjective judgments. I was satisfied that that method would be satisfactory and also that the Swedes have the technical expertise and a sense of social responsibility to do it properly. Perhaps I should have made the distinction yesterday that the existence of technology does not necessarily guarantee that in all cases that technology will be used, or used responsibly and competently. TALK.START.PARA: —In a supplementary question this afternoon Senator Durack questioned the pedigree of my statement that the Government's intention had been to introduce an Australian Bill of Rights as part of a total package of human rights legislation. In reply, I said that the decision was made last December and that I had issued a statement at that time. I am afraid I have to acknowledge that I misled the Senate as to the date on which the Government decision and my statement were made. In fact it was not in December but some weeks earlier on 25 October. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the full text of that statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MAJOR HUMAN RIGHTS LEGISLATION PLANNED
Cabinet has authorised me to proceed with a package of major human rights legislation, the centrepiece of which will be a national Bill of Rights.
The Bill of Rights is likely to be introduced into the Parliament late this Session and will lie on the table for a period sufficient to allow full public discussion before beind debated.
The human rights package, which was part of Labor's pre-election policy and has been the subject of active planning for the past 6 months, will include three main elements;

an Australian Bill of Rights, which will act as an inspirational and educative charter providing general guarantees of basic rights and freedoms, and be accompanied by provisions for administrative and limited judicial enforcement;

amendments to the structure, role, jurisdiction and enforcement powers of the Human Rights Commission, together with machinery amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the proposed Sex Discrimination Act to strengthen and integrate those provisions into a comprehensive scheme; and
amendment of the substantive provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act.

The Bill of Rights will be based on the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), ratified by Australia in 1980, which requires the Government to respect and to ensure to all individuals the rights recognised in the Covenant, without distinction of any kind, such as race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status.

The Bill will deal with such basic rights as the rights to freedom of expression, conscience, religion and assembly, and rights relating to the protection of privacy and with respect to the criminal process. It will provide a yardstick against which restrictions of these rights by both written laws and government action can be measured.

One of the main aims of the Bill of Rights will be to make everyone in this country aware of just what the fundamental rights and freedoms in a democratic society are, and to remind people that rights and freedoms which they regard as precious to themselves are possessed in equal measure by all others.

However, legislative guarantees, apart from their value as declaratory and educative mechanisms, are of little value unless they can be given practical expression. Complaints about breaches of rights will be able to be investigated by a strengthened Human Rights Commission, and in addition the Bill will provide for limited judicial enforcement.

So far as enforcement by the courts is concerned, the intention at this stage is that the guarantees in the Bill of Rights should operate as ''rules of construction''. This would mean that they could be called in aid by any person in the course of any criminal, civil or tribunal proceeding in which the application of some other statutory provision or a common law rule is involved, but could not be relied upon directly to found an action for an injunction, variation of contract, damages or such like.
A Task Force on Human Rights, involving departmental officers and external consultants, has been established to assist in the preparation of the Bill of Rights and the other elements of the package.

So far as the review of the Racial Discrimination Act is concerned, the Task Force has placed advertisements in the major metropolitan dailies and the ethnic press calling for submissions from the public and special interest groups. Major issues for consideration here include:
how best to deal with race-hatred propaganda;
the best way to apply and enforce anti-discrimination measures;
the relationship between the Racial Discrimination Act and the Aboriginal land rights legislation.

I believe that all Governments in Australia have a role to play in protecting human rights and am aiming at establishing, in consultation with the States, a set of legislative and administrative arrangements by which that responsibility can be shared.

Whilst it is important for the Commonwealth to be the standard bearer in human rights matters, the Government's policy is that Federal measures should not infringe upon constructive developments which have been taking place in some States in the human rights field and which are consistent with our international obligations.

Co-operative enforcement arrangements between the Human Rights Commission and State human rights and anti-discrimination bodies will continue to be developed and strengthened, with the aim ultimately of providing ''one stop shopping'' for complaints under both Commonwealth and State law.

Federal legislation is, however, required not only to implement our international obligations but because in such an area as individual rights and freedoms the Commonwealth's responsibility is also a trust. It would be completely unacceptable for the basic rights of some Australians to be protected while others are left vulnerable.
When the Bill of Rights is introduced it will lie on the table to enable further consultation with the States and for community discussion and comment to take place.
The Governments present intention is for all three elements in the proposed legislative package to be debated together in the Autumn 1984 Parliamentary Session.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 March Senator Martin asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, three questions. The first was: How many employees has the Health Insurance Commission recruited from the private health funds since August 1983? The second was: What is the total number of additional Health Insurance Commission employees since 1983? The third question was: How many of the former private health fund employees were recruited on a temporary contract basis and how many on a permanent basis? The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has provided the following anwsers. The answer to the first question is that 1,073 have been recruited from the private health funds, 834 full time staff and 239 part time staff. The answer to the second question is 2,582, comprising 1,565 full time staff and 1, 017 part time staff. The answer to the third question is 1,073 staff.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, the Commission has taken on 1,073 ex-fund staff so far and estimates that it will take on another 123. There is scope for taking on substantial additional numbers of ex-fund staff through the process of terminating the employment of short term staff. Of course, such an approach carries substantial risks for efficiency in Medicare processing, since it involves laying off trained, satisfactory staff and recruiting untrained fund staff whose level of competence is unknown at this stage. Many ex-fund staff may not be attracted by the part time employment opportunities available in the Commission.

The extent of co-operation received from funds in resolving staff surplus problems has varied from State to State. The following comments focus on the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia in Queensland which recently issued redundancy notices to more than 80 staff, apparently without warning. The Commission held initial discussions with MBF in mid-November 1983 when it was hoped that a reasonable level of co-operation would occur. The attitude of MBF changed and for a time it declined to discuss the subject further. The Commission was unaware of the recent retrenchment action by MBF until staff who had received redundancy notices contacted the Commission in Queensland. The Medical Benefits Fund subsequently provided the Commission with lists of staff. Recent discussions with MBF management have been an improvement on the indifference shown since November 1983.

The Commission is currently holding applications from only 50 of those given retrenchment notices and expects that it will be able to assist with job offers to about 36 of these subject, of course, to their suitability. The positions involved will almost certainly be part time only, that is, involving on average about four hours per day each. Progress to full time employment in due course would depend upon the availability of vacancies and the ability of the new recruits to compete with the claims of other part time staff for the transfer to full time duty.

The lack of co-operation exhibited in Queensland and repeated in New South Wales is in marked contrast to the co-operative and helpful attitude shown in South Australia and Western Australia where the Commission and the funds have worked objectively to minimise the staffing problems associated with the introduction of Medicare.
