DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to abandon its resource rent tax proposal to end the damaging uncertainty being inflicted on Australia's resource development .
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has brought forward the matter of public importance, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to abandon its resource rent tax proposal to end the damaging uncertainty being inflicted on Australia's resource development .

We bring it forward even though there is but a limited opportunity for us to deal with matters of public importance on Friday sittings. The maximum time allowed for discussion is one hour and accordingly there will be only a very limited debate. But we believe that this is a matter of very great importance to Australia. It is a matter which properly should be the subject of some discussion and we would wish the Opposition's view to be quite clear. I suppose that one of the notable, and indeed one of the worst, features of the period of the Whitlam Government in the mid-1970s was virtually the end of oil exploration in Australia. That occurred because of a combination of circumstances, but we would say that the Whitlam Government had a very significant role to play in it. We do not want to see the same thing happen in Australia during this period of Labor Government. For that reason we think it is important that the Government should move to clarify its stance on this very contentious issue.

This is not an issue where concern is limited to a partisan opposition. A great deal of concern has been expressed on behalf of the industry which is involved. Of course, it is very easy for the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), in debate at least to brush off that objection as being one of self- interest. But I remind the Senate that it is not just the Liberals, it is not just the National Party of Australia, it is not just the industry which has expressed its doubts about the resource rent tax. When the Premier of my State of Western Australia, the Hon. Brian Burke, was in the United States of America he made it quite clear that he had reservations about what his colleagues in Canberra were doing. I am sure that many honourable senators, and certainly many members of the public, would have seen reports of a dinner or luncheon at which Mr Burke spoke and answered questions. I quote what Mr Burke said in New York about a month ago, on 29 February, in response to a question about resource rent tax.

My quite frank view is that the tax is unlikely to be imposed as from 1 July. Although the announcement of its application has been made, I am sure that it is with much less joy that the National Government embraces the concept than it embraced it from the Opposition Benches.

I think that comment is as good an illustration as the Senate could ask, and indeed as the Minister could ask, of the sorts of reservations which go beyond the reservations of self-interest and partisan politics. I put very seriously to the Minister in this debate that the Government would serve the national interest better if it ended the damaging and continuing speculation which has taken place about this tax and if it made the position quite clear. It is not a matter to be left until Budget time. We have an undertaking by the Government that a new tax will be introduced to run from 1 July. There is obviously deep concern about this decision. It is obvious that it is already affecting investment decisions. It is in the national interest that the uncertainty should be brought to an end.

We bring this matter before the Senate again in the real hope that the Government will be able to see its way clear to abandon a course of action which is obviously erroneous. We hope that the Government will see the error of its ways and that it will respond to the doubts which have been expressed so broadly about what it is advocating. The Minister has plenty of precedent for this. He is not going to be a lonely figure in the Government if he reconsiders what may have been an unwise proposition. The Minister who sits next to him, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, has had to reconsider the assets test proposal that he has been carrying forward from the last Budget. The Treasurer ( Mr Keating) who the Minister for Resources and Energy represents in this place, has had to make some statements about capital gains tax which indicate that there have been shifts in the direction of the Australian Labor Party. Certainly , whilst it may be a matter that is under examination, it is not a matter which is under examination for the next Budget.

With respect to uranium policy, the Minister himself has, I think, performed a real public service in bringing forward suggestions for change in the policy area which he himself has described, I think in fairly critical terms, as confusing as it is at present worded. His colleague just across the avenue, the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, has within the last week told us that the Government has reconsidered bringing forward the Human Rights Bill at this stage . Certainly it is not going to bring it forward in a fettered pre-election atmosphere. Of course that same colleague, Senator Evans, has within the last year given us the on-again off-again constitutional proposals.

I mention those because I believe that the Government has shown quite extraordinary flexibility in areas where there is clear political opposition. I believe that most of the things that I have mentioned have been put aside, not because of the strength of argument which has been put to the Government but because of the possible electoral consequences. I do not for a moment dismiss the possibility of straight intellectual application to the problem in terms of trying to improve the Government's approach in some of those areas, but there is a common denominator in those areas of shifts of policy: They represent some electoral threat to a government which is particularly open to persuasion where it sees the possibility of some shake to its present rather substantial majority as far as public opinion polls are concerned. Perhaps that is why resource rent tax is a particularly difficult issue. I suppose that in the case of that tax the affected constituency in the short term is a much narrower one. It does not control a lot of votes. It is simply an industry which has a vital role in the longer term in trying to ensure that Australia has the maximum achievable continuing self-sufficiency in oil.

I ask the Minister not to be too coloured in his judgments by the fact that in this case he is not dealing with a mass of taxpayers who might wreak electoral vengeance on the Government. We all know that is not the case. What we have here is an industry which is made up of a relatively limited number of companies. These companies do not necessarily automatically give rise to a feeling of warmth out there among the voters, because of course they are seen as being large and powerful companies. But I say with great seriousness to the Minister and to the Government, that those companies which are searching for oil and which over the last six or seven years have been successful in improving Australia's long term oil self-sufficiency prospects do in fact represent a most important constituency, not in voting terms but in terms of the long term welfare of every person in this country. Given the debate which has gone back and forth, given the lack perhaps of electoral pressure on the Government in this area, I can only ask the Minister to apply his intellect to the serious problems which have been raised and to the very real prospect that what he and the Government are doing will in fact damage the oil search in Australia and do something to reproduce the sort of difficulties which occurred under Mr Whitlam and which I am sure the Minister does not wish to see repeated.

The recent weeks have seen a very active campaign against the resource rent tax by the industry most directly affected. I wish to emphasise in this debate that the Opposition's stance on this matter is not a stance which follows that extensive public campaign by the industry. We made our stance very clear. We have questioned the Government about its development of this proposal. From as early as May last year we have raised the issues of difficulty. I am sure this matter was raised before that. However, I know it has been raised since the last election when this subject came within my area of responsibility. We have raised questions about the difficulties we see facing the Government in this matter. But as it became more and more apparent that the Government was not going to match its theory with a practical working model we firmed up our opposition and on 27 February I announced, on behalf of the Opposition, that we wished the Government to withdraw its proposal for a resource rent tax on oil and gas.

I think that the Government, again, should stop and think about the very public campaign which has been waged by the industry. Senator Walsh should not be so quick to brush it off as being simply a campaign of self-interest. I remind the Minister for Resources and Energy and the Government that, in the main, business has been very responsive to attempts by the Government to involve business in dialogue with the Government. I believe that business in general has shown in public a broadly co-operative attitude to the Government. I say that in no critical sense. I believe that all Australians should treat the Government of Australia as the Government, but do not believe it is open to the Minister or any other member of the Government to suggest that business interests have set themselves against the present Government. Indeed, I ask the Government to think about the many pressures on business to conform with the Government's wishes and to remain quiescent and acquiescent when the Government is making moves. The Government has many opportunities to improve the lot of business or to worsen it . In the main, there is a wish to remain on good terms with the government of the day.

The fact that the companies through the agency of their organisation, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, have undertaken this campaign should underline to the Government how seriously in practical terms industry sees this Government proposal. This unique response by an industry body to a government proposal during the life of the present Government underlines the fact that there is a deep concern that the Government is about to make a substantial error that will be of long term damage to industry and in the long term against the public interest.

I also make clear to the Government that the Opposition has a growing concern at the effects of what the Government proposes and at the Government's apparent indecision. I say 'indecision' because of the rumours flying around about the fact that the Government may not proceed on this matter-the sorts of rumours which have been commented on publicly by Premier Burke in New York. The indications are that in some sections of the industry there is already a reluctance to invest, there is already a sense of uncertainty and foreboding about what the future holds, and that decisions are being delayed. I am sure that the Minister, who has a large department of state at his disposal, has available to him intelligence that is as good as or better than that which is available to the Opposition. Perhaps he receives more filtered messages than are coming through to the Opposition. I assure him that the messages I am receiving show a level of uncertainty which is already affecting investment decisions. If the Opposition's conviction that the Government's proposal is damaging not just in theory but also in current fact is correct, the Opposition believes it is important that the Government should act as soon as possible to put to rest the fears in the industry.

One of the fundamental concerns of the Opposition-a concern which has been expressed by the industry-is that the maximum self-sufficiency for Australia must be maintained. I do not want to quibble with the Minister or engage in a silly, theoretical debate about maximums. I am sure the Minister and the public know what I mean. Australia must maintain the highest practical level of oil self-sufficiency. Therefore, it should gear its policies in such a way as to take that proper objective into account. The reasons for concern about Australia 's self-sufficiency were well expanded on by the Minister for Resources and Energy in a recent speech in Sydney, on 27 March this year. I refer the Senate to page 5 of the typescript of that speech. The Minister's words tend to underline the non-partisan nature of the concern expressed by the Opposition in this debate. The Minister in that speech made clear that the current trends in industry in reduction of energy usage:

. . . may lead some to believe that we can now take a more relaxed approach to energy policy, particularly in the petroleum sector. Such complacency holds dangers: in particular any relaxation now could reverse many of the hard won achievements of recent years. There remains considerable uncertainty about oil prices and supply. Much will depend upon the effects on the world and Australian oil markets of economic recovery. In addition, the possibility of a further oil crisis arising from the Middle East situation should not be dismissed. The war between Iran and Iraq has the potential to disrupt seriously the world and Australian oil markets.

The Minister went on in more detail, and I do not have time in this debate to quote him fully. I merely embrace many of his arguments in that speech which illustrated for that audience the need to pursue self-sufficiency in oil in Australia and a high level of exploration to achieve that objective.

I believe that the Minister has indicated in that and in other speeches that he shares our fundamental approach. The danger is that he will ignore that fundamental and simply pursue the revenue objectives of the Government in the next Budget, and make decisions that are inimical to that objective. I go along with the Minister in his Sydney speech when he said:
I stress that good reason exists for maintaining the development of policies that encourage the continuing exploration and development of Australian oil.

I go along with the Minister in that passage. I do not go along with him in his present stance that the introduction of a resource rent tax in the terms he now proposes will not damage that objective.

The debate is continually distracted by red herrings. I suggest that the Minister is not guiltless in that regard. I would like to clear from this debate any concern that he might have that there are other factors affecting the oil search other than government policy on taxation. I agree with the proposition that a decline in real oil prices and in usage will affect the incentive to search for oil. Of course it will. The fact of the matter is that, as the Minister recognised in that speech, a combination of factors will affect the oil search. The Minister said in that speech on the subject of oil:
The rate at which it will be discovered and the degree to which it will be recovered are functions of price and technology as well as government taxation and other policies.

That is self-evidently correct, but the important matter of which I would remind the Minister is that government cannot affect many of those factors. It cannot affect the geology or the world price in any sensible way, and in many respects it cannot affect usage. But it will have the sole influence on the other factor involving taxation policies. If it is true, as I think it is, that other conditions at the moment are against the improvement of oil search in Australia, and if the decline in real prices and usage are against the incentive to search for oil, then for heaven's sake government policies should not buttress those negative factors but contest and oppose them.

My speaking time in this debate is almost at an end, and I wish to make only two more points in the remainder of my remarks. First, I again remind the Senate that the oil industry along with the resource industry generally faces many problems. In many respects Australia is not competitive with the rest of the world. We are not productive in our labour force, our costs are high, and there are many reasons why industrialists and investors are discouraged from pursuing development projects in this country. I do not need to remind the Government of the case put so well and so forcibly by Mr James Strong of the Australian Mining Industry Council in a speech during the last week. From the point of view of the general health of the resource industry, clearly this is not the time for the Government to be doing things that are negative and against the interests of those resource industries. But most of all, I remind the Minister of how far he has removed himself from the theoretical objectives that he was pursuing originally. The broad canvas he sketched out originally, that we should pursue profit-based taxes that would overtake the plethora of other taxes and charges and produce an economically rational single line of taxation-I know I oversimplify the argument but it is at the heart of the proposition the Minister was trying to sell-no longer sits with the practical model that he is proposing.

The Minister is now proposing a quite limited resource rent tax on a limited sector of the resource industries, the off-shore oil and gas industries. That will produce its own distortions in relation to on-shore and off-shore exploration. The Minister has gone away from the idea of setting a threshold on the basis of a wonderfully theoretical assessment of the level of return that is required to attract investment to a situation where he has set himself and the Government revenue targets that will dictate the sorts of figures that will have to be applied. I submit that the Minister has lost the theoretical justification for what he is seeking to do. He should follow another course and quickly put this matter to rest. He should indicate that the Government will not proceed with the resource rent tax. The Minister should let the Government pursue its revenue requirements, whatever they are, with a more rational approach rather than seek to destroy an industry that is so important to Australia's continuing welfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I state at the outset that the Australian Democrats support the concept of a resource rent tax. It is part of our policy. It will not be thrown out because there is an election looming. I believe that it is helpful for honourable senators and political parties going into an election to know the stance of the Australian Democrats, in the same way as we indicated that we support such things as a capital gains tax and do not go soft on those issues just because an election is looming.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Government is in a dilemma about whether to consult or not consult on this issue, because it is damned if it does and damned if it does not. Consultation results in such things as the assets test fiasco which was pilloried around the country by people who in many cases did not even understand what was being proposed. Such things as the Medicare-type confrontations result from public consultation as does the conflict within the Government's own ranks that we have seen recently over uranium. Of course, this Government and any Government which consults with the community before it puts down its final legislation is bound to draw flak.

On the other hand, it has distinct advantages. It achieves a degree of consensus before the legislation hits this Parliament. It also gives to senators and members and indication of public reaction, the public feeling on the issues. I think that that gives all parties outside and inside the Parliament an opportunity to contribute a lot more intelligently. It has one other very valuable by-product; that is, that it allows the Government to review and to adjust its approach to the planned legislation. But, of course, this means that the Government can not only review and adjust, but also in the lead-up to an election it can go soft on some of these issues, as we have seen with capital gains and wealth taxes. It is interesting that it is not going soft on resource rent taxes; perhaps that is because there are no votes coming from the international oil comapnies in the next election.

I believe that the changes to resources taxes are inevitable. I think every political party sees it as an inevitability of the evolving tax system. As we have a declining proportion of old oil it has to change. But I also believe, and I agree with the Opposition, that it needs to be changed quickly. We need to give tax certainty for the future. That applies to the good economic health not only of the oil companies, but also of the Australian economy. I believe that all will benefit from a decision in principle being announced in the near future , certainly not just broad guidelines, but a decision which puts some meat on the bones and which gives the oil companies the opportunity to plan ahead for the many years for which they are obliged to plan ahead because of the nature of the industry that they are in.

I am a little nonplussed as to why we have this matter of public importance before us today. A number of important issues are far more vital than this. On 2 March we debated a matter of public importance also put down by the Leader of the Opposition in this House, which read:
The continuing uncertainty being created by the Government's proposal to introduce a resource rent tax.
Today's matter is only mildly modified. It reads:
The urgent need for the Government to abandon its resource rent tax proposal to end the damaging uncertainty being inflicted on Australia's resource development .

One wonders why this matter has been repeated. Is it a lack of awareness by the Opposition of other major issues, or is it a need to demonstrate to oil companies its ongoing support? Is it in opposition to the Government's public debate method in such major matters as taxation? Having posed that rhetorical question, I think we also need to ask why there should be a resource rental tax. As it is our policy to support such a concept, I will briefly go over the benefits that the Australian Democrats see coming from a resource rent tax.

First, there are no taxes before profits are made. In the exploration business that is absolutely vital. It encourages a proliferation of explorers, large and small, and it also encourages exploration of marginal areas because of the fact that there is no tax during the exploration period. Thus exploring companies go in knowing exactly what the risk is. One of the advantages that will flow from having a resource rent tax is that the future tax policy of this Government and, once established, of future governments will be firm; it will be recognised throughout the world as a stable tax policy for explorers. That will result in an attraction to explorers to come to this country because stability above all else appeals to oil companies and oil explorers. The very thought of nationalisation of discovered oil is anathema to oil explorers. Australia does not have such a policy in prospect from any of the major political parties. With a resource rent tax policy, it would have a policy which would last for decades. I do not think that anybody is arguing that there should not be some tax on Australian resources so that Australians can share the proceeds and the benefits that flow from the discoveries of oil and other minerals.

Most oil producing nations have a resource rent tax or something similar unless they have nationalised their oil industries. I am sure that the Liberal and National Parties are not suggesting that there be no tax on oil. But it is interesting that in the two debates that we have had on these similar matters of public importance an alternative suggestion has not been proposed. As we come out of the old oil-new oil syndrome obviously we have to have an alternative. I find it rather depressing that all the Opposition can do is knock the proposal which is being advanced by the Democrats and by the Government without putting forward an alternative. It is interesting also that the Opposition, particularly the Liberal Party, had dabbled with a resource rent tax since 1977 when it announced it was examining that possibility. One wonders whether it might still be hidden somewhere in its policy or its policy in prospect.

I think we also need to ask why the oil majors are opposing this resource rent tax. We even need to ask whether they are opposing the resource rent tax or whether they are simply jockeying themselves into a bargaining position. They may be taking a leaf out of the book of the Australian Medical Association and putting themselves into a position of holding their hands out for something pretty good at the start, better down the track, and, they hope, the best of all possible worlds at the end of the track. The strategy they are adopting seems to follow that particular path. I stress in particular the strategy of putting up straw men and knocking them over. Across my desk and across the desks of all honourable senators have come in the last few days a couple of quite interesting documents, one from the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd and the other from a major oil exploration company, Esso. The difficulty that I have with each of these documents is this: Not only are they putting up straw men; their whole case is built on a fallacy. They start with the proposition that a resource rent tax would, of itself, automatically increase the tax burden on the oil exploration companies. That does not necessarily apply to all oil companies. It may increase the Government's tax revenue but it does not follow that it will increase the tax burden on all of the oil companies. In fact, if it does have the effect, as we saw in Bass Strait when there was a change in oil policy, of increasing it on some who can afford it but reducing it on other potential and existing explorers, that may be to Australia's benefit and to the benefit of the industry itself. To start with that fallacious foundation and build the case on that is, I believe, less than honest. The Esso document uses the same foundation stone of increased taxation. It expresses it in these terms:
Australia's oil self-sufficiency will be lower with an RRT-
There is the threat of decreased exploration. I repeat:
Australia's oil self-sufficiency will be lower with an RRT and increased taxation-
as a concomitant of that, I interject-
leading to more oil imports, less government revenue, less jobs and leaving the country vulnerable to the uncertainties of supplies from the Middle East.

Now that does not follow. There is a lack of logic in that argument. There may well be, as a result of a change in the tax pattern, a substantial increase in oil exploration in this country. There may well be a move towards much more marginal areas of oil exploration, which at this moment may not be worth tapping under the old tax regime. The second point made by Esso is this:

Australia's oil prospectivity is close to the lowest in the world and an RRT and increased taxation will reduce exploration, especially the high-cost, high- risk offshore oil search for the major discoveries Australia needs.

That completely ignores the big benefit of exploring in and around this nation and that is the stability of government and the potential stability of government policy with a resource rent tax. The third point states:

RRT has major theoretical problems because it ignores the basic fact that the prospect of high rewards is the driving force of exploration psychology. High tax added to high risk is the wrong policy for Australia's oil indpendence.

I ask the question: What high tax? I have not seen a tax rate quoted. What rate of tax is contemplated? Until that is known it is not honest to propose that this high tax is going to be imposed and will add to the high risk for oil exploration.

I believe that the Government's approach is respectable. I believe that the issuing of a discussion paper to the public at large, the invitation to the industry to comment on that discussion paper, the issuing of a second paper which will give a lot more substance to the concept, and then accepting criticism, comment and suggestions on that second paper, I hope before bringing in the legislation in the near future, is a respectable approach to the introduction of such new legislation, such a new approach to taxation in this country. I believe that the Government does not warrant criticism for having the debate in the community. I think it could be encouraged to get on with the job now, to indicate very quickly to the industry and to the world at large what the new policy will be. I believe government and industry now should sit down at the round table and resolve any outstanding issues with this new resource rent tax and implement it will before the commencement of the next financial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —After 12 months in opposition the Liberal Party is giving the Government gratuitous advice on how to govern, which I suppose is something Oppositions normally do. So recently after the previous Government, the present Opposition, was so thoroughly discredited, it does take a fair amount of cheek to be giving gratuitous advice to the new Government on how to run the country, particularly when one looks at the record that was left behind by the last Government and inherited by this one. There was a declining real gross domestic product, an actual shrinkage of the economy, an increase in its last twelve months in office of a quarter of a million in the number of people unemployed, an 11.5 per cent inflation rate and rising, record interest rates and a prospective $10 billion deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I will comment briefly on what Senator Jack Evans said. He put many of the arguments for a resource rent tax, and I do not propose to reiterate them. He also criticised the Opposition for putting forward a motion that the Government should abandon its resource rent tax proposal, but he did not make clear whether the Opposition is also saying that any alternative form of tax should also be abandoned. I would certainly welcome some indication from the Opposition as to whether its view is that there should be no tax at all, other than those which exist, or that there should be some tax at some rate other than a resource rent tax. I think Senator Evans very properly criticised the Opposition for that. In spite of that, there is a good deal of common ground between the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. It does not make political or economic sense for any government consciously to adopt a policy that would lead to a major reduction in oil exploration effort, particularly when our practical self-sufficiency cannot be guaranteed for a very long period.

Senator Chaney suggested that the Goverment was pushing on with this proposal because the oil companies are seen to be politically vulnerable. That is because oil companies per se, or their general managers and directors, do not have many votes in total. I think he is probably right in that political assessment, especially if a government should choose to attack oil companies in emotional or even xenophobic terms. I think it is recognised, even by Senator Chaney, that the Government has not criticised or attacked oil companies in that way. We have endeavoured to conduct this debate on a rational basis and we will continue to do so. Senator Chaney clearly assumes that the introduction of a resource rent tax will necessarily cause exploration to decline relative to what it would have been without the introducion of a resource rent tax. He seems to have reached that conclusion regardless of the rate at which a resource rent tax would apply and regardless of the extent of any exploration subsidy or offset.

Really, a responsible judgment as to whether a different tax regime will cause exploration to go up or down cannot be made until figures are known on rates, thresholds and the degree of offset subsidy. I think the Opposition would have had more credibility if it had criticised the Government, as Senator Evans did, albeit in a rather mild way, for not having actually produced those hard figures , at this stage, three months before the proposed commencement date. That type of criticism would have had some credibility, but the Opposition chose instead to call upon the Government to abandon the rent tax policy, without making it clear whether it proposed some alternative tax or whether it proposed no tax at all.

Senator Chaney made the point that practical self-sufficiency in oil is an important objective, and I agree. It does not necessarily follow that it is an objective which should be pursued at any cost or exclusive of any other objective. For example, if maximising our known oil reserves and our rate of oil production were the only economic objectives of a government-this applied to the previous Government, too-a government would abolish the existing ad valorem royalty which applies to new oil discoveries. It might even consider abolishing corporate tax on companies involved in oil exploration or alternatively consider some form of exploration subsidy with or without the existence of a resources rent tax. So this matter has to be seen in perspective. Even the last Government did not pursue the goal-I would have been amazed if it had-of maximising exploration effort and, hopefully, discovery rates exclusive of all other goals.

Senator Chaney mentioned the industry campaign. It ought to be noted that that is not a campaign against a resources rent tax per se; it is a campaign against any tax on new oil other than that which already exists-that is, the ad valorem royalty-be it on-shore or off-shore, and the exposure, with a one-year delay, of oil producers to corporate taxation. The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association campaign is directed against any form of tax, not simply a resources rent tax. We must bear in mind when comparing a rent tax with an alternative tax that the industry is not monolithic. At least five actual or significant potential producers have told the Government, sometimes in public and sometimes in private, that they favour a rent tax as against an alternative tax which would yield comparable amounts of revenue.

The whole industry has a common interest-if it looks only at the industry interest-in trying to minimise the tax that government imposes upon it. However, the whole industry does not have a common interest in opposing a particular type of tax. A particular type of tax, be it a rent tax, the existing levy or a variant of that, will affect different companies in different ways. It is not surprising that specific companies react to proposals for levies as an alternative to a rent tax or vice versa in accordance with what they perceive to be their interest. They may not necessarily be the interests of the entire industry or of all the companies involved in the industry, let alone of the economy and society as a whole.

Senator Chaney quoted from a speech that I made three days ago. I make no comment on that except to say that it related to a broader reference than simply maximising oil production. It appeared in the context of the substitution of different types of fuel for oil and also greater efficiency in the use of oil and other fuels. He claimed that I had moved a long way from the original proposal. I certainly do not think that is entirely valid because it has been recognised by me from the outset that in most areas the States have primary control in the application of the principle of rent taxation and it could not be achieved without State co-operation. He also quoted a statement by the West Australian Premier in New York a couple of weeks ago. Mr Burke does not have current information on the stage this Government has reached and so is not well placed to make such a comment. He was entitled to give his opinion but it was not a well-informed opinion.

Senator Mason made a point that I had intended to make in any case. I guarantee that the tax regime we are proposing, once installed, will not be overturned by a subsequent Liberal government. I would hope that a subsequent Liberal government will not tamper with the rates either. I do not believe that, once a rent tax system is in operation, a subsequent Liberal government will overturn it.

In the five minutes that remain to me, I will comment briefly on a couple of more technical aspects. As I have stated from the beginning, a rent tax applied to Bass Strait oil would necessarily, because of the imperative of Government revenues, have to be applied at a quite high rate and at a rate which yielded revenue at least equal to that which would have been yielded by the existing excise. Revenue neutrality in the first year under a rent tax or, alternatively, an excise system is maintained on projected production levels for a number of years but in about five years hence ceases to be revenue neutral because under the existing excise system fields would be declining through the progressive schedule that applies to the present excise whereas a rent tax would, barring only negative cash flows, continue to apply at a constant rate. In the Bass Strait situation and with the existing projected levels of production, revenue neutrality in the short term does not guarantee or even provide revenue neutrality in the longer term.

The Government has proposed all along that coincidentally with the introduction of a rent tax the existing ad valorem royalty be abolished and that an exploration offset, more recently in the form of a subsidy, be offered. I want to comment on both of those things. I am a little surprised that at least so far industry reaction indicates that the industry places little importance on the provision of an exploration subsidy. That is demonstrated particularly in the published comments of Esso Australia Ltd, but by no means only Esso, and perhaps to a lesser extent from the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I am surprised by that reaction because it does influence quite significantly the numerical model which the industry uses to develop its exploration programs. However, given that at least to this stage the industry reaction to an exploration subsidy seems to have been close to indifferent, it may well be worth putting to the industry a proposition that the alternatives would be a rent tax at a lower rate without an exploration subsidy or a rent tax at a higher rate with an exploration subsidy. The Government is currently considering that.

In regard to the simultaneous abolition of the existing ad valorem royalty, it ought to be noted-I know this is known by industry but it is probably not appreciated by the general public-that in assessing the impact of a rent tax or a rent tax rate, an adjustment should be made for the abolition of the royalty. Depending on the particular production costs in various fields, that notional RRT rate should be adjusted downwards by at least 12 1/2 per cent and perhaps by as much as 20 per cent to gauge the real impact of such a tax compared to the existing arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 20 per cent of the rate or by 20 per cent?

—It would be 20 per cent of the rate. I do not have time to explain all the reasons. As I said, it depends on the actual production costs within a particular field, the degree to which the payment of RRT as against an excise is delayed and a number of other factors. The bare minimum figure is 12 1 /2 per cent; it might rise later.
—The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the extra few minutes that we have available, I raise a matter which has been brought to my notice by a constitutent concerning an approach by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to her, as a citizen, in relation to the household expenditure survey being conducted. I inform the Minister at the table, the Minister for Veteran's Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), that I have had several inquiries from constituents in the last few weeks about different aspects of the work of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The first approach made to me was by an elderly patient, who was concerned about the impending visit of a collector. She was worried about admitting anyone to her home. It was possible to approach the Bureau, to get complete co-operation and to overcome that problem. The Bureau was able to offer me, through very helpful officers in Sydney, methods to overcome that problem. I am grateful for that.

SPEECH.PARA: A constituent from the south coast who contacted me recently had another concern. She said that what is required of her in relation to this household expenditure survey is that, for a period of, I think, a fortnight, she is required to record all expenditures and also to answer a number of other questions about her financial commitments and obligations. She has two objections. One is a practical objection. Trying to cope with her financial obligations, she has two jobs. She and her husband simply do not have the time to carry out what she said is several hours of work each week to fill in the information required. Secondly she is concerned that her privacy is being invaded by some of the questions. For example, there are queries about the ways in which she has financed the purchase of her home and to whom she owes money. She believes that the question of to whom she owes money is a matter between her and the person from whom she has borrowed and is not a matter involving government. I hope that a reasonable approach can be worked out for the information to be gathered with the least concern being caused to the person. Unfortunately, she has tried to approach officers who have made contact with her through the Bureau of Statistics and has been told she must carry out what is required and that a sanction of $100 fine a day is what awaits her if she does not do what is required.

It seems to me that we are in a bit of a dilemma. We need the information for purposes of national information gathering and for certain planning activities-I do not deny that, nor does she. We require the co-operation of citizens otherwise we cannot get the information. But there is an element in her complaint with which I have sympathy. She has personal problems in relation to her commitments of time. She does not have time to spend on herself. She does not know how she will find the time to fill in the forms. Also, she has very real concerns about the invasion of privacy in gathering some of the information required. I ask the Minister: Is it possible to approach the Bureau? I would act as an honest broker to try to make some contact with the person, but I really believe there is a way through this that would fall far short of having to invoke the penalty provisions of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act in relation to this lady that would enable all sides to make an accommodation which would meet the needs of all concerned. I hope that we can find a resolution to this problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume has raised a very important matter which, there is no doubt, requires some refinement. As he said, we need the information. It is important for government to have that information, as it is important for government to have the information obtained from the census when it comes around every few years. The difficulty of course is having working in the field people who appreciate the difficulties of individual households, as there are and individuals within households who may not be able to provide the information freely and fairly, without feeling thatthey are under duress, under threat of penalties and so on. I feel, as I am sure the Government would feel, that that situation ought not to arise.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no intention to invade the privacy of individuals. Nevertheless, if we do not have the co-operation of individuals the survey loses a great deal of its purpose. We need universal information, but we need it to be given freely and consciously. If it is not provided in that way, clearly the survey will not produce the accurate results that we are looking for. I will certainly bring this matter to the attention of the appropriate Minister. I think the persons conducting the survey on behalf of the Commonwealth need to do so with a great deal of tact and understanding. If there is resistance, perhaps more time should be provided and more tolerance shown. To that extent I think the honourable senator has done the Government a service in bringing this matter to the attention of the Government. Whilst we rely upon a wide range of people to assist us in the collection of this information, we also need to rely upon the co-operation of citizens. That co-operation should be freely given. The value of their co-operation should be pointed out to them. A breakdown in communication is possibly a factor in the matter raised by Senator Baume.

This matter probably comes under the jurisdiction of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young). I am not sure whether that is so; I am talking off the top of my head. Certainly the appropriate Minister will have Senator Baume's remarks drawn to his attention. I think we probably need to advise the persons working in the field to show tact and understanding in the way in which they deal with citizens so that the information will be forthcoming. It is vital information for government so that it can ascertain community needs and plan its future legislative programs in a way that is fair and equitable. I undertake to see that this matter is brought to the attention of the appropriate Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 4.09 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government given any consideration to include thorium, a nuclear fuel, in safeguards arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Monazite exported from Australia contains small quantities of thorium. Exports of monazite are currently taking place for the extraction of rare earths and, in some cases, thorium for non-nuclear industrial uses. Under existing arrangements , monazite exports are subject to approval by the Minister for Trade on a shipment-by-shipment basis to countries which have given assurances as to the non-nuclear end-use of the thorium contained in the monazite. The question of export of thorium or ores containing thorium (for example monazite) for nuclear end-use has not arisen to date.

The Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) Inquiry is currently examining a number of issues relating to Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle, including safeguards issues. In considering ASTEC's report the Government will be looking at the adequacy of the current arrangements relating to thorium.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1983 (Hansard, page 528) Senator Macklin asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the fact that Australian wine is exempt from sales tax. Is the Minister aware that the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation has decided that wine produced from Australian tropical fruits is not exempt from sales tax? Can the Minister give any reason for such a decision? Will the Government support an amendment to the Sales Tax Act when it next comes before the Senate so that Australian tropical fruit wine can be placed on a par with grape wine.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that Australian wine is exempt from sales tax under sub-item 36 (4) in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax ( Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The term 'wine' is not defined in the sales tax law but the exemption has been interpreted by the Taxation Office for many years as applying only to wine derived from the fermented juice of grapes. Various beverages made from other fruits are often referred to as wine but prefixed by the name of the variety of fruit, for example tropical fruit wine, pear wine (commonly known as perry), apricot wine, blackberry wine and so on. Some varieties are not made from fruit, for example, honey wine (usually referred to as mead) and rice wine (known as saki). These beverages are taxable at the general rate of 20 per cent.

(2) An amendment of the law would be necessary to exempt tropical fruit wines from sales tax. The Government is not able to give the assurance of support for such an amendment that is sought in the question. However, the matter will be reviewed in the context of the 1984-85 Budget deliberations.
